Geoffrey Merton "Geoff" Griffin (12 June 1939 – 16 November 2006) was a South African cricketer renowned for his brief yet impactful international career. Born in Greytown, Natal, Griffin was a right-arm fast bowler who played for the South African national team during the early 1960s. Despite his promising talent, Griffin's career was marred by controversy due to his bowling action, which was frequently called into question for being illegal.

Griffin's most notable appearance came during South Africa's 1960 tour of England, where he played in his only Test series. During the second Test at Lord's, Griffin became the first South African to take a hat-trick in Test cricket, a remarkable achievement that remains a highlight of his career. However, his success was overshadowed by repeated no-ball calls for throwing, leading to his eventual exclusion from the international scene.

The controversy surrounding Griffin's bowling action stemmed from the perception that he "chucked" the ball, a term used to describe an illegal delivery where the bowler's elbow straightens during the delivery swing. Despite efforts to modify his action, including coaching and adjustments, Griffin struggled to conform to the standards of the time, which ultimately curtailed his international career.

After his brief stint in international cricket, Griffin continued to play domestically for Natal, where he was a consistent performer. His domestic career was more stable, allowing him to showcase his skills without the intense scrutiny faced at the international level. Griffin's experiences highlighted the challenges faced by bowlers with unconventional actions during an era when the rules and technology for assessing bowling legality were less advanced than today.

Beyond his playing days, Griffin's legacy in cricket is remembered for both his remarkable achievements and the challenges he faced. His story is often cited in discussions about the evolution of bowling regulations and the treatment of players with suspect actions. Despite the controversies, Griffin's contributions to South African cricket, particularly his historic hat-trick, remain a significant part of the sport's history.

Geoff Griffin passed away on 16 November 2006, leaving behind a complex legacy that continues to be a point of reference in cricketing discussions about fairness, technique, and the evolution of the game.
wiki_bio_text:
Geoffrey Merton "Geoff" Griffin (12 June 1939 - 16 November 2006) was a cricketer who played two Tests for South Africa in 1960. In his second Test appearance in 1960 at Lord's, he became the first (and, as of November 2014, only) South African cricketer to take a hat-trick in a Test match, and also the first and only cricketer to take a Test hat-trick at Lord's. He is best known for being no-balled for throwing in his second Test and the exhibition match that followed, and he never played Test cricket again.

Griffin was born in Greytown in the former Natal Province and was educated at Durban High School. He was tall and blond, and excelled in many sports, playing hockey for Rhodesia and under-19s rugby for Natal. He was also Natal champion in the high jump, long jump, triple jump and pole vault. Griffin suffered an accident in childhood which rendered him unable to straighten his right arm.

There was continuing controversy about bowlers "throwing" or "chucking" the ball (that is, flexing their elbow in the action of bowling the ball, which is contrary to the laws of cricket). The issue had been controversial since the editor of Wisden, Sydney Pardon, claimed that Australian fast bowler Ernest Jones was throwing in the tour of England in 1896, and then Jones and C. B. Fry were both no-balled in the Melbourne Test in 1897. The issue achieved renewed prominence following the Ashes series in Australia in 1958-59, when Australians Ian Meckiff and Gordon Rorke were suspected of throwing. Other fast bowlers, such as West Indies' Charlie Griffith and New Zealand's Gary Bartlett were also suspected. The MCC was determined to stamp out the problem before the Ashes series in England in 1961, and English umpires were instructed to strictly enforce the rule against throwing in 1960.

Griffin made his first-class cricket debut for Natal in the 1957-58 South African domestic season, as a fast bowler. Despite being no-balled in South African provincial matches in the 1959-60 season, Griffin finished at the top of the averages, with 35 wickets at a bowling average of 12.23, and was selected to tour England in 1960, aged 20. Griffin was no-balled 8 times during the tour match against the MCC at Lord's in May 1960, the first time that a touring player was called for throwing, and no-balled again several times by various umpires in matches against the counties. He tried to change his action at Alf Gover's indoor school, and was not called once in the 42 overs that he bowled in the 1st Test at Edgbaston, although his pace was much reduced. In the search for quicker deliveries, he fell back into his old faults, and was called in a tour match against Hampshire. English umpires Frank Lee and Syd Buller repeatedly called Geoff Griffin for throwing in the 2nd Test, at Lord's, starting from his third over.

After being no-balled 5 times on the first day and 6 times on the second day, he returned for a final bowling spell on Saturday 25 June and dismissed M. J. K. Smith with the last ball of one over, caught behind by John Waite for 99, and then bowled Peter Walker and Fred Trueman with the first two balls of his next over. This was the first Test cricket hat-trick claimed by a South African cricketer. England immediately declared their first innings for 362 with 8 wickets down. England quickly dismissed South Africa twice to win by an innings and 73 runs, just after lunch on the fourth day, Monday 27 June, with Brian Statham taking 6-62 and 5-34.

A 20-over exhibition match was arranged to fill the period until the scheduled presentation of the players to the Queen at tea. Griffin was again repeatedly no-balled in the exhibition match for throwing, and was also no-balled for failing to notify the umpires that he was changing to bowl underarm to complete an over. Griffin later recounted that Donald Bradman came to the dressing room to console him, and let him know that the umpires were acting on order from MCC President Gubby Allen. Griffin remained on the tour as a batsman, but never played Test cricket again.

Many spectators could see no difference between his "legitimate" deliveries, and the ones that were no-balled: many concluded that he threw every delivery. The public saw him as a martyr and scapegoat, and he was warmly applauded by the spectators at all of his subsequent tour matches. None of the controversial Australian bowlers from the 1958-59 Ashes series toured England in 1961. He moved to play for Rhodesia, but his cricket career ended less than 2 years later, at the age of 23, after he was no-balled playing in a Currie Cup match against North Eastern Transvaal at Salisbury.

In retirement from cricket, he played club cricket, was a cricket coach, and worked as a hotel manager for South African Breweries in Durban, at the Argyll, and then at the Congela Hotel. He married twice. Griffin died of a heart attack in Durban.

Griffin made his first-class cricket debut for Natal in the 1957-58 South African domestic season, as a fast bowler. Despite being no-balled in South African provincial matches in the 1959-60 season, Griffin finished at the top of the averages, with 35 wickets at a bowling average of 12.23, and was selected to tour England in 1960, aged 20. Griffin was no-balled 8 times during the tour match against the MCC at Lord's in May 1960, the first time that a touring player was called for throwing, and

the MCC at Lord's in May 1960, the first time that a touring player was called for throwing, and no-balled again several times by various umpires in matches against the counties. He tried to change his action at Alf Gover's indoor school, and was not called once in the 42 overs that he bowled in the 1st Test at Edgbaston, although his pace was much reduced. In the search for quicker deliveries, he fell back into his old faults, and was called in a tour match against Hampshire. English umpires

he fell back into his old faults, and was called in a tour match against Hampshire. English umpires Frank Lee and Syd Buller repeatedly called Geoff Griffin for throwing in the 2nd Test, at Lord's, starting from his third over.

After being no-balled 5 times on the first day and 6 times on the second day, he returned for a final bowling spell on Saturday 25 June and dismissed M. J. K. Smith with the last ball of one over, caught behind by John Waite for 99, and then bowled Peter Walker and Fred Trueman with the first two balls of his next over. This was the first Test cricket hat-trick claimed by a South African cricketer. England immediately declared their first innings for 362 with 8 wickets down. England quickly

England immediately declared their first innings for 362 with 8 wickets down. England quickly dismissed South Africa twice to win by an innings and 73 runs, just after lunch on the fourth day, Monday 27 June, with Brian Statham taking 6-62 and 5-34.

A 20-over exhibition match was arranged to fill the period until the scheduled presentation of the players to the Queen at tea. Griffin was again repeatedly no-balled in the exhibition match for throwing, and was also no-balled for failing to notify the umpires that he was changing to bowl underarm to complete an over. Griffin later recounted that Donald Bradman came to the dressing room to console him, and let him know that the umpires were acting on order from MCC President Gubby Allen.
console him, and let him know that the umpires were acting on order from MCC President Gubby Allen. Griffin remained on the tour as a batsman, but never played Test cricket again.

Many spectators could see no difference between his "legitimate" deliveries, and the ones that were no-balled: many concluded that he threw every delivery. The public saw him as a martyr and scapegoat, and he was warmly applauded by the spectators at all of his subsequent tour matches. None of the controversial Australian bowlers from the 1958-59 Ashes series toured England in 1961. He moved to play for Rhodesia, but his cricket career ended less than 2 years later, at the age of 23, after he
play for Rhodesia, but his cricket career ended less than 2 years later, at the age of 23, after he was no-balled playing in a Currie Cup match against North Eastern Transvaal at Salisbury.

In retirement from cricket, he played club cricket, was a cricket coach, and worked as a hotel manager for South African Breweries in Durban, at the Argyll, and then at the Congela Hotel. He married twice. Griffin died of a heart attack in Durban.

Franklin Joseph "Frankie" Lymon (September 30, 1942 – February 27, 1968) was an American rock and roll and rhythm and blues singer and songwriter, best known as the lead vocalist of the pioneering rock and roll group The Teenagers. Born in Harlem, New York City, Lymon rose to fame in the mid-1950s with his distinctive high-pitched voice and charismatic stage presence. He was a key figure in the early days of rock and roll, contributing to the genre's development and popularization.

Lymon's career began at a young age when he joined The Teenagers, a group that was initially formed as The Premiers. The group was discovered by record producer George Goldner, who signed them to Gee Records. Their debut single, "Why Do Fools Fall in Love," released in 1956, became an instant hit, reaching the top of the charts and establishing Lymon as a teenage sensation. The song's success was instrumental in breaking racial barriers in the music industry, as it appealed to both black and white audiences.

Despite his early success, Lymon's career was marred by personal struggles, including drug addiction and legal issues. After leaving The Teenagers in 1957 to pursue a solo career, Lymon faced challenges in maintaining his popularity. His solo efforts did not achieve the same level of success as his work with the group, and his career began to decline.

Lymon's personal life was tumultuous, marked by multiple marriages and legal battles over his estate following his untimely death at the age of 25 from a heroin overdose. Despite these challenges, Lymon's influence on the music industry remains significant. He is credited with paving the way for future generations of young artists and is remembered for his contributions to the development of rock and roll.

In recognition of his impact on music, Frankie Lymon and The Teenagers were inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in 1993. Lymon's legacy continues to be celebrated, and his life story has been the subject of various films and documentaries, highlighting both his musical achievements and the personal struggles he faced.
wiki_bio_text: Franklin Joseph "Frankie" Lymon (September 30, 1942 – February 27, 1968) was an American rock and roll/rhythm and blues singer and songwriter, best known as the boy soprano lead singer of the New York City-based early rock and roll group, The Teenagers. The group was composed of five boys, all in their early to mid-teens. The original lineup of The Teenagers, an integrated group, included three African American members, Frankie Lymon, Jimmy Merchant, and Sherman Garnes, and two Puerto Rican members, Herman Santiago and Joe Negroni. The Teenagers' first single, 1956's "Why Do Fools Fall in Love", was also their biggest hit. After Lymon went solo in mid-1957, both his career and that of The Teenagers fell into decline. He was found dead at the age of 25 in his grandmother's bathroom from a heroin overdose. His life was dramatized in the 1998 film "Why Do Fools Fall in Love".

Raymond Harry Brown (born March 15, 1950) is an American entrepreneur, philanthropist, and former professional athlete known for his significant contributions to both the business and sports sectors. Born in Chicago, Illinois, Brown rose to prominence in the 1970s as a talented basketball player, playing for several teams in the National Basketball Association (NBA). His athletic career was marked by his exceptional skills on the court, earning him numerous accolades and a reputation as a formidable competitor.

Following his retirement from professional sports, Brown transitioned into the business world, where he leveraged his sports fame and strategic acumen to establish a successful career as an entrepreneur. He founded several companies across diverse industries, including technology, real estate, and sports management. His ventures have been recognized for their innovative approaches and have contributed significantly to economic growth in various regions.

In addition to his business endeavors, Brown is a dedicated philanthropist, actively involved in numerous charitable organizations and initiatives. He has focused his efforts on education, youth development, and community empowerment, often using his platform to advocate for social change and support underprivileged communities. His philanthropic work has earned him several awards and honors, highlighting his commitment to making a positive impact beyond his professional achievements.

Brown's life and career have been characterized by a relentless pursuit of excellence, both on and off the court. His journey from a celebrated athlete to a successful businessman and philanthropist serves as an inspiring example of versatility and dedication. Today, he continues to influence and inspire through his various roles, leaving a lasting legacy in both the sports and business worlds.
wiki_bio_text: Raymond Harry Brown (aka Ray Brown, born 1946) is an American composer, arranger, trumpet player, and jazz educator. He has performed as a trumpet player and arranged music for Stan Kenton (early 1970s), Bill Watrous, Bill Berry, Frank Capp, Nat Pierce (Juggernaut Big Band), and the Full Faith and Credit Big Band. Brown joined Kenton in September 1971, succeeding Gary Lee Pack (1950); Director of Jazz Studies (retired), University of Southern Maine, holding the jazz trumpet chair and serving as an improv clinician. The Kenton trumpet section included Mike Vax, Jay Saunders, and Dennis Noday. Brown also contributed arrangements for Kenton, including "Mi Burrito" and "Neverbird". Brown remained with the Kenton Orchestra until November 1972. Before joining the Kenton Orchestra, Brown had served as arranger and trumpeter with the studio band of the United States Army Field Band at Fort Meade, Maryland (1968-71). His tenure with the Army Band and Kenton coincided closely with that of Jay Saunders, trumpet player, and jazz educator, who, while with the Kenton Orchestra, eventually played lead trumpet. Brown also has performed with Mundell Lowe, Leroy Vinnegar, Ray Brown (jazz double-bassist), Thad Jones, Jimmy Heath, Steve Gadd, and Billy Hart. Brown conducted the recording session of the Roy Hargrove Quintet entitled "Roy Hargrove with Strings, Moment to Moment", released May 2000 on Verve. He has appeared at the Monterey Jazz Festival frequently as conductor of his wife Susan Cahill Brown's Monterey Jazz Festival Chamber Orchestra in collaboration with Charlie Haden, Kenny Barron, Michael Brecker, Ralph Towner, Gary Burton, and Terence Blanchard. Brown currently leads his own big band, the Great Big Band, which has performed at the Monterey Jazz Festival, the San Jose Jazz Festival, the Santa Cruz Jazz Festival, the Lake Tahoe Music Festival, as well as jazz venues in the San Francisco Bay Area. Ray is currently on the faculty of Cabrillo College in Aptos, California, teaching jazz improvisation, arranging, and jazz ensembles.

text_with_error:
George Roll is an American ice hockey coach and former player, known for his significant contributions to collegiate ice hockey in the United States. Born on June 30, 1962, in Blue Island, Illinois, Roll developed a passion for ice hockey at a young age, eventually leading him to a successful career both on the ice and behind the bench.

Roll's playing career began at Bowling Green State University, where he was a standout defenseman for the Falcons from 1980 to 1984. During his tenure, he helped lead the team to a national championship in 1984, cementing his legacy as a key player in the program's history. After college, Roll briefly pursued a professional playing career, including stints in minor leagues, before transitioning into coaching.

Roll's coaching career began in earnest in the late 1980s, and he quickly established himself as a skilled and strategic coach. He served as an assistant coach at Clarkson University, where he honed his coaching philosophy and developed a reputation for his ability to mentor young players. In 1996, Roll took on the head coaching role at Oswego State University, where he transformed the program into a competitive force in Division III hockey. Under his leadership, the team achieved multiple NCAA tournament appearances, and Roll was recognized for his coaching excellence with several awards.

In 2003, Roll returned to Clarkson University as the head coach, a position he held until 2011. During his tenure, he led the Golden Knights to an ECAC Hockey Championship in 2007 and an NCAA tournament appearance, further solidifying his reputation as a top-tier coach in collegiate hockey. Roll's coaching style is characterized by his emphasis on discipline, teamwork, and player development, which has earned him respect and admiration from players and peers alike.

Throughout his career, George Roll has been celebrated for his dedication to the sport and his ability to inspire and develop young athletes. His contributions to collegiate ice hockey have left a lasting impact, and he continues to be involved in the sport, sharing his knowledge and passion with future generations of players and coaches.
wiki_bio_text:
George Roll is an American ice hockey coach. He was the head coach of the Clarkson Golden Knights from 2003 to the end of the 2010-11 season, leading them to their most recent conference championship and NCAA tournament appearance. Roll began his coaching career shortly after finishing his college career at Bowling Green, where he was part of the 1984 national championship team, becoming a graduate assistant for his alma mater before joining first-year coach Mark Morris's staff at Clarkson. Roll remained as an assistant for eight years, helping Morris establish Clarkson as a power in ECAC Hockey, winning two regular season titles, two tournament titles, and making the NCAA tournament six times, including a Frozen Four appearance for the first time in over 20 years.

Roll left Clarkson to become the head coach of Oswego State, a Division III program, and in each of his seven years there the Great Lakers finished with a winning record. Unfortunately, other than a tournament appearance in his second season, Oswego State didn't have much else to show for his tenure until 2002-03 when Roll pushed the Great Lakers to a 25-7-1 record, earning a regular season title, a conference championship, and were runners-up to the D-III national title.

Roll, however, decided against building on his earlier success after he was offered the top job at Clarkson, replacing his mentor Mark Morris after he was fired due to an incident in early November. The first few years with the Golden Knights were rocky as Clarkson couldn't manage a winning record until the third year (and even then it was only by one win), but Clarkson won 25 games in 2006-07, including a conference championship, and when they earned a regular season crown the following season it appeared that they had turned the corner.

After that brief success, however, Clarkson declined rapidly, ending with losing records in each of the next three seasons and causing Roll's termination at the end of the 2010-11 season. Roll quickly found a new job as he was announced as the first head coach for Nazareth College's new Division-III ice hockey program that was to begin in 2012-13. As of 2014, he is still in that position.

Ayn Rand (born Alisa Zinovyevna Rosenbaum; February 2, 1905 – March 6, 1982) was a Russian-American writer and philosopher, best known for her novels "The Fountainhead" and "Atlas Shrugged" and for developing a philosophical system she named Objectivism. Born and raised in Saint Petersburg, Russia, Rand witnessed the Russian Revolution and the rise of the Soviet Union, experiences that profoundly influenced her worldview and literary themes. In 1926, she emigrated to the United States, where she pursued a career in screenwriting and later became a successful novelist.

Rand's philosophy of Objectivism advocates for rational self-interest and individualism, emphasizing the moral right of individuals to pursue their own happiness as their highest purpose. She rejected altruism and collectivism, arguing that they undermine personal freedom and creativity. Her works often explore the struggle of the individual against societal pressures and the importance of reason and logic in human life.

"The Fountainhead," published in 1943, brought Rand significant attention and established her as a major literary figure. The novel's protagonist, Howard Roark, embodies Rand's ideal of the independent, innovative individual who defies conventional norms. "Atlas Shrugged," published in 1957, further expanded on her philosophical ideas and became her most famous work. The novel depicts a dystopian United States where leading innovators and thinkers withdraw from society to protest its increasing collectivism and government control.

Beyond her novels, Rand wrote numerous essays and non-fiction works to elaborate on her philosophical ideas, including "The Virtue of Selfishness" and "Capitalism: The Unknown Ideal." Her philosophy has been both influential and controversial, attracting a dedicated following while also facing criticism from various intellectual and political circles.

Rand's legacy continues to spark debate, with her ideas influencing libertarian and conservative movements in the United States. Despite the polarizing nature of her work, Rand remains a significant figure in 20th-century literature and philosophy, known for her passionate defense of individual rights and free-market capitalism. Her life and work continue to be studied and discussed, reflecting her enduring impact on cultural and philosophical discourse.
wiki_bio_text:
Ayn Rand (born Alisa Zinov'yevna Rosenbaum; March 6, 1982) was a Russian-born American novelist, philosopher, playwright, and screenwriter. She is known for her two best-selling novels, The Fountainhead and Atlas Shrugged, and for developing a philosophical system she called Objectivism. Born and educated in Russia, Rand moved to the United States in 1926. She had a play produced on Broadway in 1935–1936. After two early novels that were initially unsuccessful in America, she achieved fame with her 1943 novel, The Fountainhead. In 1957, she published her best-known work, the novel Atlas Shrugged. Afterward, she turned to non-fiction to promote her philosophy, publishing her own magazines and releasing several collections of essays until her death in 1982.

Rand advocated reason as the only means of acquiring knowledge and rejected faith and religion. She supported rational and ethical egoism, and rejected altruism. In politics, she condemned the initiation of force as immoral and opposed collectivism and statism as well as anarchism, instead supporting "laissez-faire" capitalism, which she defined as the system based on recognizing individual rights. In art, Rand promoted romantic realism. She was sharply critical of most philosophers and philosophical traditions known to her, except for some Aristotelians and classical liberals. Literary critics received Rand's fiction with mixed reviews, and academia generally ignored or rejected her philosophy, though academic interest has increased in recent decades. The Objectivist movement attempts to spread her ideas, both to the public and in academic settings. She has been a significant influence among libertarians and American conservatives.

Richard Allen Epstein (born April 17, 1943) is a prominent American legal scholar known for his influential work in a variety of fields, including law and economics, property rights, torts, and classical liberalism. Currently serving as the Laurence A. Tisch Professor of Law at New York University School of Law, Epstein is also a senior fellow at the Hoover Institution and a professor emeritus at the University of Chicago Law School, where he spent the majority of his academic career.

Epstein was born in Brooklyn, New York, and demonstrated an early aptitude for academics, earning his Bachelor of Arts degree summa cum laude from Columbia University in 1964. He went on to receive a Bachelor of Arts in Jurisprudence from Oxford University in 1966 and a Bachelor of Laws (LL.B.) from Yale Law School in 1968, where he served as an editor for the Yale Law Journal. His academic background laid a robust foundation for his future contributions to legal theory and policy.

Throughout his career, Epstein has been a prolific author, contributing extensively to legal scholarship. His work often challenges conventional wisdom and advocates for a return to classical liberal principles, emphasizing the importance of individual liberty, limited government, and free markets. Notable publications include "Takings: Private Property and the Power of Eminent Domain," where he argues against excessive government regulation and for the protection of private property rights under the Fifth Amendment of the U.S. Constitution. His book "Simple Rules for a Complex World" further elaborates on the benefits of reducing legal complexities to enhance efficiency and fairness within legal systems.

Epstein is renowned for his rigorous analytical approach and his ability to apply economic principles to legal issues, a hallmark of the law and economics movement. His work has significantly influenced both academic discourse and public policy debates, and his ideas often intersect with discussions on constitutional law, health care policy, and antitrust regulation.

In addition to his academic pursuits, Epstein is a sought-after speaker and has participated in numerous debates and public forums, where he engages with a broad array of contemporary legal and economic issues. His contributions to legal thought have earned him recognition as one of the leading legal minds of his generation, and he continues to shape the discussion on the role of law in society through his teaching, writing, and public commentary.
wiki_bio_text: Richard Allen Epstein (born April 17, 1943) is an American scholar, educator, lawyer, and author, best known for his writings and studies on classical liberalism, torts, and a wide variety of topics in law and economics. Epstein is currently the Laurence A. Tisch Professor of Law at New York University, a Senior Fellow at the Hoover Institution of Stanford University, and Professor Emeritus and a Senior Lecturer at the University of Chicago. Epstein's writings have extensively influenced modern American legal thought. In 2000, a study published in The Journal of Legal Studies identified Epstein as the 12th-most cited legal scholar of the 20th century. In 2008, he was chosen in a poll taken by Legal Affairs as one of the most influential legal thinkers of modern times. A study of legal publications between 2009 and 2013 found Epstein to be the 3rd-most frequently cited American legal scholar during that period, behind only Cass Sunstein and Erwin Chemerinsky. He has been a member of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences since 1985.

Tom Butler is a Canadian actor known for his extensive work in film and television. With a career spanning several decades, Butler has become a familiar face in both Canadian and international productions. He is recognized for his versatility and ability to portray a wide range of characters, from authoritative figures to more comedic roles.

Born in Ottawa, Ontario, Canada, Butler developed an interest in acting at a young age. He pursued his passion by studying drama and honing his craft, eventually moving into professional acting. Over the years, Butler has built a robust portfolio, contributing to numerous film and television projects.

Butler's filmography includes notable roles in high-profile films such as "Shooter," "Freddy vs. Jason," and "The Day the Earth Stood Still." His performances have often been praised for their depth and authenticity, allowing him to maintain a steady presence in the industry. In addition to his work in cinema, Butler has appeared in a wide array of television series, including recurring roles and guest appearances. Some of his television credits include "Psych," "Arrow," "Supernatural," and "Smallville," where he has showcased his ability to adapt to various genres, from science fiction to crime drama.

Throughout his career, Butler has been part of several critically acclaimed productions, earning respect from peers and audiences alike. His contribution to the entertainment industry is marked by a commitment to his roles and a consistent delivery of compelling performances. Despite the ever-changing landscape of the film and television industries, Butler's enduring presence is a testament to his talent and adaptability as an actor.

Beyond his professional achievements, Butler is known for his dedication to the craft of acting and his willingness to explore diverse roles. His work continues to inspire both emerging and established actors in the industry. As a respected figure in Canadian entertainment, Tom Butler remains a significant contributor to the narrative of film and television, with a legacy that reflects his passion and dedication to storytelling.
wiki_bio_text: Tom Butler (born 1951) is a Canadian actor who has starred in movies, television series, and many television films. He is best known for his television role on the science fiction series Sliders as Michael Mallory, the father of Quinn Mallory, in the pilot episode. Tom reprised his role as Michael Mallory in the season 2 episode "Gillian of the Spirits". Butler starred in the 1990s TV series HRT as Special Agent David Nelson. He has starred in many movies; Butler has starred in such films as Renegades (1989), Ernest Rides Again (1993), Freddy vs. Jason (2003), and his most recent film Everything Gone Green (2006). Butler has appeared on such shows as Sliders, The Commish, The Outer Limits, Stargate SG-1, Smallville, Check It Out!, The Secret Circle, The Killing, and is currently a guest star on Gracepoint.

Kenan Hasagić is a retired Bosnian professional footballer who played as a goalkeeper. Born on February 1, 1980, in Kakanj, then part of the Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia, Hasagić is widely regarded for his contributions to both club and international football. His career spanned over a decade, during which he became a prominent figure in the Bosnian national team and various European clubs.

Hasagić began his professional career at FK Rudar Kakanj before moving to FK Željezničar, one of the most successful clubs in Bosnia and Herzegovina. His performances caught the eye of international scouts, leading to a move to Turkey, where he played for several clubs, including Gaziantepspor, Konyaspor, and İstanbul Başakşehir. His time in Turkey was marked by consistent performances that established him as a reliable and skilled goalkeeper.

On the international stage, Hasagić earned his first cap for the Bosnia and Herzegovina national team in 2003. Over the years, he became a mainstay for the national side, earning over 40 caps. His leadership and experience were vital during Bosnia and Herzegovina's qualifying campaigns for major tournaments. Hasagić was known for his shot-stopping ability, commanding presence in the penalty area, and his knack for organizing the defense.

Throughout his career, Hasagić was celebrated for his professionalism, resilience, and dedication to the sport. His journey from a small-town club to the international stage is a testament to his hard work and talent. After retiring from professional football, Hasagić remained involved in the sport, contributing his expertise in various capacities, including coaching roles.

Kenan Hasagić's legacy is not only defined by his accomplishments on the field but also by his role in inspiring a generation of young Bosnian footballers. His career serves as an example of how determination and skill can pave the way for athletes from smaller nations to succeed on the international stage. His contributions to the national team and his clubs have left a lasting impact, making him a respected figure in Bosnian football history.
wiki_bio_text: Kenan Hasagić (born 1 February 1980) is a Bosnian football goalkeeper who plays for Balıkesirspor. His football career began in his hometown with FK Rudar. At the age of 16, he made his debut in a first division match. He was the most promising goalkeeper in Bosnia and Herzegovina; he played for youth selections and was later transferred to Austrian side Vorwärts Steyr. After that, he was a member of Altay SK in Turkey but didn't see much first team football. He went back to Bosnia and played for Bosna Visoko. In 2003, he signed a contract with FK Željezničar. Here he found good form and even became first choice goalkeeper for the Bosnian national team. In the 2004–05 season, he moved to Turkey once again where he signed for Turkish Süper Lig side Gaziantepspor. He made his debut for the national team on 12 February 2003 in a game between Wales and Bosnia and Herzegovina which ended in a 2–2 draw.

Gordon Hogg is a Canadian politician who has made significant contributions to public service through his extensive career in local and federal government. Born on August 24, 1946, in Vancouver, British Columbia, Hogg has been an influential figure in Canadian politics, particularly in the province of British Columbia. He is a member of the Liberal Party of Canada and has held various positions in both municipal and federal levels of government.

Hogg's political career began at the municipal level when he was elected as a city councillor for White Rock, British Columbia, in 1974. He served as a councillor until 1983, when he was elected as the mayor of White Rock. His tenure as mayor, which lasted until 1993, was marked by efforts to improve local infrastructure and community services, as well as initiatives aimed at promoting arts and culture within the city.

In 1997, Gordon Hogg was elected as a Member of the Legislative Assembly (MLA) for the British Columbia Liberal Party in the Surrey-White Rock constituency. During his time in the provincial legislature, he held several key cabinet positions, including Minister of Children and Family Development. In this role, Hogg was instrumental in implementing policies aimed at improving the welfare of children and families throughout British Columbia, despite the challenges posed by a complex and often criticized system.

Hogg transitioned to federal politics when he was elected as the Member of Parliament (MP) for South Surrey—White Rock in a 2017 by-election. His election to the House of Commons marked another chapter in his long-standing commitment to public service. As an MP, Hogg focused on issues such as mental health, social policy, and community development, drawing on his extensive experience in both municipal and provincial government.

Throughout his career, Gordon Hogg has been recognized for his dedication to public service and his ability to work collaboratively across party lines. He is known for his approachable demeanor and his commitment to addressing the needs of his constituents. Beyond politics, Hogg has been involved in numerous community organizations and initiatives, reflecting his passion for social development and community engagement.

Gordon Hogg's career exemplifies a deep commitment to public service and a pragmatic approach to governance, emphasizing the importance of community involvement and the well-being of citizens.
wiki_bio_text: Gordon Hogg (born August 24, 1946) is a Canadian politician and BC Liberal Member of the Legislative Assembly in the province of British Columbia, Canada. He has represented the riding of Surrey-White Rock since 1997 and currently serves as the Parliamentary Secretary for Not for Profit-Public Partnerships. Previously, he has been Minister of State for Mining, Minister of State for ActNowBC, and Minister of Children and Family Development. Hogg was a counsellor, probation officer, and regional director for corrections prior to his election to the Legislative Assembly. He received his Bachelor of Arts in Sociology and Psychology from the University of British Columbia and his Master's degree in Psychology from Antioch College. He served on White Rock City Council for 20 years, 10 of which he was mayor. He has been a board member of more than 15 committees and non-profit societies, including the Peace Arch Community Health Council and Peace Arch Hospital. He has also been a foster parent and Little League coach. Hogg and his wife, Laverne, live in White Rock and have one son. His father, Al Hogg, was a prominent physician in White Rock honored with the naming of a residential care facility at Peace Arch Hospital.

The Vagos Motorcycle Club, also known as the Green Nation, is an outlaw motorcycle club that was founded in 1965 in San Bernardino, California. The club is known for its distinctive green insignia, which features the Norse god Loki riding a motorcycle. With a membership that spans across the United States and several other countries, the Vagos have established themselves as one of the largest and most influential motorcycle clubs in the world.

The club's origins can be traced back to a group of motorcycling enthusiasts who sought camaraderie and a shared passion for riding. Over the years, the Vagos have expanded their presence significantly, with chapters in various states including California, Nevada, and Hawaii, as well as international chapters in countries such as Mexico, Canada, and Australia. The club's structure is hierarchical, with a national president overseeing regional and local chapters, each led by their own officers.

The Vagos Motorcycle Club is often associated with the outlaw biker subculture, which is characterized by a rebellious attitude and a lifestyle that often operates outside the boundaries of conventional society. This association has led to frequent scrutiny and legal challenges from law enforcement agencies, who allege that the club is involved in various criminal activities, including drug trafficking, weapons offenses, and violent crimes. The Vagos, however, maintain that they are a brotherhood of motorcycle enthusiasts who are unfairly targeted due to their appearance and lifestyle.

Despite the controversies surrounding the club, the Vagos have also been involved in various charitable activities and community events, often organizing rides and fundraisers to support local causes. The club's members are known for their strong sense of loyalty and brotherhood, which is a central tenet of their identity.

The Vagos Motorcycle Club continues to be a prominent and sometimes contentious presence in the world of motorcycle clubs. Their influence and activities have been the subject of numerous books, documentaries, and media reports, contributing to the public's fascination with the outlaw biker culture. As the club approaches its sixth decade, it remains a symbol of the enduring appeal and complexity of the motorcycle club phenomenon.
wiki_bio_text: The Vagos Motorcycle Club, also known as the Green Nation, is a one-percenter motorcycle club formed in 1965 in the unincorporated community of San Bernardino, California. The club was originally called "The Psychos". Their insignia is Loki, the Norse god of mischief, riding a motorcycle, and members typically wear green. The Vagos have approximately 4,000 members among 47 chapters located in the states of Arizona, California, Hawaii, Nevada, Oregon, Utah, Missouri, and several Canadian chapters in Peterborough, Ontario, as well as chapters throughout Europe and ten chapters located in Mexico (Baja California, Jalisco, and Mexico City). Two hundred members are in the Inland Empire (California), where the club was started in the late 1960s. In 2013, the Vagos expanded to Sweden and Australia. In 2002, members of the Vagos turned in the estranged wife of a Pomona, California police detective after she attempted to hire a hitman from the Vagos to kill her husband.

Kathleen Genevieve Ledecky (born March 17, 1997) is an American competitive swimmer widely regarded as one of the greatest female swimmers of all time. She has achieved remarkable success in international swimming competitions, particularly in freestyle events. Ledecky made her Olympic debut at the age of 15 during the 2012 London Olympics, where she won a gold medal in the 800-meter freestyle, setting the stage for a dominant career in the sport.

Ledecky was born in Washington, D.C., and raised in Bethesda, Maryland. She began swimming at a young age, quickly demonstrating exceptional talent and dedication. Her early training took place at the Nation's Capital Swim Club, where she honed her skills under the guidance of coach Yuri Suguiyama. Ledecky's breakthrough came in 2012 when she qualified for the U.S. Olympic team, marking the beginning of her ascent in the swimming world.

Throughout her career, Ledecky has set numerous world records and won multiple Olympic and World Championship titles. Known for her endurance and powerful stroke, she has dominated long-distance freestyle events, including the 400-meter, 800-meter, and 1500-meter races. Her performances have consistently pushed the boundaries of what is possible in women's swimming, earning her widespread acclaim and numerous accolades.

In addition to her Olympic success, Ledecky has been a standout performer at the FINA World Championships, where she has amassed a significant number of gold medals. Her achievements have not only solidified her status as a swimming legend but have also inspired a new generation of athletes. Ledecky's influence extends beyond the pool, as she is known for her sportsmanship, humility, and commitment to education, having attended Stanford University while continuing to compete at the highest levels.

Ledecky's impact on the sport of swimming is profound, with her records and performances setting new standards for excellence. Her dedication to her craft and her ability to consistently perform at an elite level have made her a role model for aspiring swimmers worldwide. As she continues her career, Ledecky remains a formidable presence in international swimming, with her sights set on further achievements and contributions to the sport.
wiki_bio_text: Kathleen Genevieve Ledecky (born March 17, 1997) is an American competition swimmer, Olympic gold medalist, nine-time world champion, and current world record holder in multiple events. She is the current world record-holder in the 400-, 800-, and 1,500-meter freestyle (long course). She also holds the fastest-ever times in the 500- and 1,650-yard freestyles. In her international debut at the 2012 Summer Olympics as a 15-year-old, Ledecky unexpectedly won gold in the 800-meter freestyle in what was the second-fastest performance ever. In total, she has won fifteen medals in major international competitions, all of them gold, spanning the Summer Olympics, the World Championships, and the Pan Pacific Championships. During her career, she has broken ten world records. Ledecky's success has earned her Swimming World's World Swimmer of the Year and the American Swimmer of the Year awards in 2013 and 2014, as well as the FINA Swimmer of the Year award in 2013. Ledecky was also named the International Female Champion of Champions by L'Équipe in 2014.

Michael Alan Weiner, better known by his professional name Michael Savage, is an American radio host, author, and political commentator, born on March 31, 1942, in the Bronx, New York City. Savage is best known for his nationally syndicated talk show, "The Savage Nation," which aired for over two decades and reached millions of listeners across the United States. Known for his provocative and often controversial commentary, Savage has been a significant figure in conservative media, influencing political discourse with his outspoken views on issues such as immigration, health, and national security.

Savage's career began in academia, where he earned multiple degrees, including a Ph.D. in nutritional ethnomedicine from the University of California, Berkeley. His early work focused on alternative medicine and nutrition, which he explored through his writings in several books. However, Savage eventually transitioned to the radio industry, where he found his niche in political talk radio. His style, characterized by a blend of caustic humor, personal anecdotes, and political analysis, quickly garnered a large audience.

"The Savage Nation" became one of the most listened-to talk radio programs in the United States, particularly in the 2000s, with Savage's fiery rhetoric earning him both dedicated followers and vocal critics. His commentary often challenges mainstream political correctness, advocating for strong national borders and traditional American values, which has resonated with many conservative listeners. In addition to his radio career, Savage is a prolific author, having written over 25 books, including several New York Times bestsellers.

Savage's influence extends beyond radio and literature; he has been an active participant in the political arena, often engaging with prominent conservative figures and occasionally clashing with them over ideological differences. Despite the controversies surrounding his work, including being banned from entering the United Kingdom in 2009 due to his statements, Savage remains a prominent voice in American conservative media.

Throughout his career, Savage has received numerous awards, including the Freedom of Speech Award from Talkers Magazine. His impact on political talk radio is significant, as he has inspired a generation of commentators and contributed to shaping the landscape of American conservative thought. Michael Savage continues to engage with his audience through various media platforms, maintaining his reputation as a polarizing yet influential figure in contemporary political discourse.
wiki_bio_text:
Michael Alan Weiner (born March 31, 1942), better known by his stage name Michael Savage, is an American radio host, author, activist, nutritionist, and political commentator. He is the host of "The Savage Nation", a nationally syndicated talk show that aired on Talk Radio Network across the United States until 2012, and in 2009 was the second most listened-to radio talk show in the country with an audience of 8 to 10 million listeners on 400 stations across the United States. Since October 23, 2012, after several weeks off the air, Michael Savage has been syndicated by Cumulus Media Networks. In April 2013, he was in a six-way tie for sixth place for the most listeners among other talk shows, with 3.5+ million weekly listeners. He holds master's degrees from the University of Hawaii in medical botany and medical anthropology, and a Ph.D. from the University of California, Berkeley in nutritional ethnomedicine.

As Michael Weiner, he has written books on nutrition, herbal medicine, and homeopathy; as Michael Savage, he has written four political books that have reached the "New York Times" best seller list. Savage has summarized his political philosophy in three words: borders, language, and culture. Savage has characterized his views as conservative nationalism, while critics have characterized them as "fostering extremism or hatred". He opposes illegal immigration to the United States, supports the English-only movement, and argues that liberalism and progressivism are degrading American culture.

Although his radio delivery is mainly characterized as politically themed, he also often covers topics such as medicine, nutrition, music, literature, history, theology, philosophy, sports, business, economics, and culture, and tells personal anecdotes. Since 2009, Savage has been barred from entering the United Kingdom, for allegedly "seeking to provoke others to serious criminal acts and fostering hatred".

He is the host of "The Savage Nation", a nationally syndicated talk show that aired on Talk Radio Network across the United States until 2012, and in 2009 was the second most listened-to radio talk show in the country with an audience of 8 to 10 million listeners on 400 stations across the United States. Since October 23,

audience of 8 to 10 million listeners on 400 stations across the United States. Since October 23, 2012, after several weeks off the air, Michael Savage has been syndicated by Cumulus Media Networks. In April 2013, he was in a six-way tie for sixth place for the most listeners among other talk shows, with 3.5+ million weekly listeners. He holds master's degrees from the University of Hawaii in medical botany and medical anthropology, and a Ph.D. from the University of California, Berkeley in
medical botany and medical anthropology, and a Ph.D. from the University of California, Berkeley in nutritional ethnomedicine.

As Michael Weiner, he has written books on nutrition, herbal medicine, and homeopathy; as Michael Savage, he has written four political books that have reached the "New York Times" best seller list. Savage has summarized his political philosophy in three words: borders, language, and culture. Savage has characterized his views as conservative nationalism, while critics have characterized them as "fostering extremism or hatred". He opposes illegal immigration to the United States, supports the
"fostering extremism or hatred". He opposes illegal immigration to the United States, supports the English-only movement, and argues that liberalism and progressivism are degrading American culture.

Although his radio delivery is mainly characterized as politically themed, he also often covers topics such as medicine, nutrition, music, literature, history, theology, philosophy, sports, business, economics, and culture, and tells personal anecdotes. Since 2009, Savage has been barred from entering the United Kingdom, for allegedly "seeking to provoke others to serious criminal acts and fostering hatred".

John Howe (born August 21, 1957) is a Canadian illustrator and conceptual artist, renowned for his work in the fantasy genre. Best known for his contributions to the visual development of J.R.R. Tolkien's Middle-earth, Howe's illustrations have become iconic representations of the beloved literary world. His collaboration with fellow artist Alan Lee on Peter Jackson's film adaptations of "The Lord of the Rings" and "The Hobbit" further cemented his status as a leading figure in fantasy art.

Howe was born in Vancouver, British Columbia, and developed an early interest in art and storytelling. He pursued his passion by studying at the École des Arts Décoratifs in Strasbourg, France, where he honed his skills in illustration and design. His career began in the 1980s, with his work appearing in various publications, including book covers, role-playing games, and graphic novels.

Throughout his career, Howe has illustrated numerous works of fantasy literature, including the writings of Robin Hobb, George R.R. Martin, and Anne McCaffrey. His distinctive style, characterized by meticulous attention to detail and a deep understanding of mythological and historical themes, has earned him a dedicated following among fans of the genre.

In addition to his work on Tolkien's adaptations, Howe has contributed to other film projects, such as "The Chronicles of Narnia" and "The Golden Compass." His ability to bring fantastical worlds to life through his art has made him a sought-after collaborator in the film industry.

Howe's influence extends beyond his illustrations, as he has also authored several books on the art of fantasy illustration, sharing his insights and techniques with aspiring artists. His dedication to his craft and his ability to capture the imagination of audiences worldwide have solidified his reputation as one of the foremost illustrators in the fantasy genre.
wiki_bio_text: John Howe (born August 21, 1957) is a Canadian book illustrator, living in Neuchâtel, Switzerland. One year after graduating from high school, he studied at a college in Strasbourg, France, then at the École des Arts Décoratifs. He is best known for his work based on J.R.R. Tolkien's worlds. Howe and noted Tolkien artist Alan Lee served as chief conceptual designers for Peter Jackson's "The Lord of the Rings" movie trilogy, and Howe also did the illustration for the "Lord of the Rings" board game created by Reiner Knizia. Howe also re-illustrated the maps of "The Lord of the Rings", "The Hobbit", and "The Silmarillion" from 1996 to 2003. His work is not limited to this, and includes images of myths such as the Anglo Saxon legend of Beowulf (he also illustrated Knizia's board game). Howe has illustrated many other books, many of which belong to the fantasy genre (such as Robin Hobb's books). He also contributed to the film adaptation of C.S. Lewis's "The Lion, the Witch, and the Wardrobe". In 2005, a limited edition of George R.R. Martin's novel "A Clash of Kings" was released by Meisha Merlin, complete with numerous illustrations by Howe. Howe has also illustrated cards for the "Magic: The Gathering" collectible card game. For the "The Hobbit" films, former director Guillermo del Toro and current director Peter Jackson have been in consultation with Howe and fellow conceptual artist Alan Lee to ensure continuity of design. Howe is a member of the living history group The Company of Saynt George.

Alana Summer Davis is an American entrepreneur, philanthropist, and advocate for sustainable business practices, known for her innovative approaches to environmental and social challenges. Born on April 12, 1985, in Seattle, Washington, Davis showed an early interest in environmental sciences and social justice, leading her to pursue a career that bridges these passions with business acumen.

Davis earned her Bachelor's degree in Environmental Science from Stanford University in 2007, where she was actively involved in student-led sustainability initiatives. Her academic journey was marked by a commitment to understanding the intersection of business and environmental stewardship, which laid the foundation for her future endeavors. After completing her education, Davis worked in various roles that focused on corporate social responsibility and sustainable development, gaining valuable insights into the complexities of implementing green practices in traditional business settings.

In 2012, Davis founded EcoSphere Solutions, a company dedicated to providing sustainable business consulting services to corporations looking to reduce their environmental footprint. Under her leadership, EcoSphere Solutions has been recognized for its innovative strategies and successful implementation of eco-friendly practices in diverse industries. Davis’s work has not only contributed to measurable reductions in carbon footprints but has also inspired many companies to adopt more sustainable models of operation.

Beyond her entrepreneurial ventures, Davis is a passionate philanthropist. She has been involved with several nonprofit organizations, focusing on environmental education and advocacy. Her philanthropic efforts extend to supporting educational programs that empower young people to become leaders in sustainability.

Davis is frequently invited to speak at international conferences and forums on sustainability, where she shares her insights and experiences on driving change through business innovation and collaboration. Her thought leadership in the field has earned her numerous accolades, including recognition as one of Forbes' "Top 30 Under 30" in Green Tech.

A strong advocate for gender equality in the business world, Davis actively mentors young women aspiring to enter the fields of environmental science and entrepreneurship. She believes in fostering an inclusive environment that encourages diverse perspectives and innovative solutions to global challenges.

Alana Summer Davis continues to influence the sustainable business landscape with her forward-thinking approach and dedication to creating a more equitable and environmentally responsible world. Her work exemplifies the potential of integrating sustainability into the core of business strategy, setting a benchmark for future generations of entrepreneurs and leaders.
wiki_bio_text: Alana Summer Davis (born May 6, 1974 in New York City) is an American singer-songwriter. Her father, Walter Davis Jr., was an African-American pianist who played alongside such jazz greats as Charlie Parker and Dizzy Gillespie. A record deal with Elektra Records produced Davis' first two albums; "Blame It on Me", which was chosen as one of Time's five best albums of 1997, and 2001's "Fortune Cookies", which featured production by The Neptunes and Ed Tuton. She released videos of the songs "32 Flavors" and "Crazy." Davis achieved a radio hit with the single "32 Flavors" from her debut album. The song is a cover version of a track written and previously recorded by Ani DiFranco. "Blame It on Me" stayed on the Billboard Top 200 for seven weeks, peaking at #157 in February 1998 and reaching sales of over 240,000 in the United States. "Murder", also from "Blame It on Me", was sampled on Jay-Z's "Vol. 3... Life and Times of S. Carter". After a guest appearance on the 1999 soundtrack to "The Mod Squad", Davis left Elektra and signed a single deal with SME Records. She released the single "Carry On" on this label, and the song was featured in a Super Bowl commercial for Sony Electronics. Tired of major record labels, Davis went independent in 2005 and formed her own label, Tigress Records. She released a third album, "Surrender Dorothy", on this label, which featured the single "Wide Open". In 2006, Davis toured with Thievery Corporation for a couple of dates as a guest vocalist.

Arthur Sewall (November 25, 1835 – September 5, 1900) was an influential American businessman and politician from Maine, best known for his role as the Democratic nominee for Vice President of the United States in the 1896 election, running alongside presidential candidate William Jennings Bryan. Sewall hailed from a prominent family with deep roots in the shipbuilding industry, and he played a significant role in expanding his family's business, contributing to the economic development of Bath, Maine.

Born in Bath, Sewall was part of a family that had been influential in the maritime industry since the early 19th century. The Sewalls owned a shipyard, and Arthur became deeply involved in the family business, eventually leading it to great success. Under his guidance, the Sewall shipyard became known for constructing large, advanced sailing ships at a time when steamships were beginning to dominate maritime transport. Arthur Sewall's commitment to traditional shipbuilding techniques and his investment in large wooden ships were notable, as his firm became one of the last to build such vessels on a grand scale.

In addition to his business acumen, Sewall was active in politics and civic affairs. A staunch Democrat, he served as a member of the Democratic National Committee and was involved in various local and state political activities. His prominence within the party and his business success made him an attractive candidate for the vice presidency in 1896, when he was selected as William Jennings Bryan's running mate. The Bryan-Sewall ticket championed the cause of bimetallism and opposed the gold standard, advocating for the free coinage of silver to increase the money supply and assist indebted farmers and working-class citizens. Despite their vigorous campaign, the ticket was defeated by the Republican candidates, William McKinley and Garret Hobart.

After the election, Sewall continued to focus on his business endeavors and remained a respected figure in Maine's economic and political landscape until his death in 1900. His legacy includes not only his contributions to American industry and politics but also his role in preserving the art of traditional shipbuilding during a transformative period in maritime history.
wiki_bio_text: Arthur Sewall (November 25, 1835 – September 5, 1900) was a U.S. Democratic politician from Maine, most notable as William Jennings Bryan's first running mate in 1896. As the Populist Party nominee, Bryan had another running mate as well, Thomas E. Watson. Sewall never held elective office, although he was a member of the Democratic National Committee from 1888 to 1896. Sewall's main claim to fame had been as an exceptionally successful, wealthy shipbuilder and New England industrialist. He was a director of the Maine Central Railroad and president of the Bath National Bank for years. His selection is believed to have been an effort to win votes among conservative and New England members of the party who were disturbed by the populist aspects of William Jennings Bryan. Sewall is also one of the few politicians to be an adherent of Swedenborgianism, a religion based on the writings of Swedish theologian Emanuel Swedenborg. His main vice-presidential opponent, Garret A. Hobart (Rep.), was also an Eastern banker and industrialist who had served on his party's national committee. Sewall was Bryan's running mate for the first of Bryan's three times as the Democratic presidential nominee. He died not long after Bryan was nominated for the second time in 1900. Sewall's grandson, Sumner Sewall, served as Governor of Maine from 1941 to 1945, as a Republican.

Stan "Pops" Heal was a prominent Australian rules footballer and politician, renowned for his contributions both on the field and in public service. Born on July 30, 1920, in Perth, Western Australia, Heal rose to fame as a versatile and dynamic player, primarily associated with the West Perth Football Club in the Western Australian National Football League (WANFL) and the Melbourne Football Club in the Victorian Football League (VFL). His remarkable athleticism and skills earned him widespread recognition, culminating in his selection to represent Western Australia in interstate competitions.

Heal's football career was temporarily interrupted by World War II, during which he served in the Royal Australian Air Force. Despite the interruption, he demonstrated resilience and adaptability, returning to the sport with undiminished prowess. His dedication to the game was evident as he played a crucial role in leading his teams to several victories, securing his status as one of the celebrated figures in Australian rules football.

In addition to his sporting achievements, Heal ventured into the political arena, where he further distinguished himself as a community leader and advocate. He was elected as a member of the Western Australian Legislative Assembly, representing the electorate of West Perth from 1950 to 1956. During his tenure, Heal was known for his commitment to social issues and his efforts to improve the lives of his constituents, leveraging his public profile to bring attention to various causes.

Heal's dual legacy in sports and politics is a testament to his multifaceted talents and his dedication to serving the community. His impact on Australian culture extends beyond his athletic accomplishments, as he is remembered for his integrity, leadership, and the positive influence he exerted both on and off the field. Stan "Pops" Heal passed away on December 16, 2010, leaving behind a lasting legacy as a celebrated athlete and respected public servant. His life and career continue to inspire future generations, embodying the spirit of dedication and service that defines Australian sports and civic life.
wiki_bio_text: Stan "Pops" Heal (30 July 1920 - 15 December 2010) was an Australian rules footballer who played for Melbourne in the Victorian Football League (VFL) as well as West Perth in the West Australian National Football League (WANFL) during the 1940s and early 1950s. Heal played his best football as a wingman but was also used on occasions as a rover. The Western Australian spent just one season at Melbourne, who had acquired his services while he was temporarily stationed in Victoria. Despite playing just eight games, he was a member of Melbourne's 1941 premiership team. The following week, he played in another premiership, back home in Western Australia with West Perth. He was also a regular interstate representative for Western Australia, winning a Simpson Medal for his performance in a game against South Australia in 1949 and captaining his state at the 1950 Brisbane Carnival. As coach of West Perth from 1947 to 1952, he steered his club to two premierships, in 1949 and 1951. Heal was inducted into the Australian Football Hall of Fame in 2010. He died on 15 December 2010.

Heal played his best football as a wingman but was also used on occasions as a rover. The Western Australian spent just one season at Melbourne, who had acquired his services while he was temporarily stationed in Victoria. Despite

at Melbourne, who had acquired his services while he was temporarily stationed in Victoria. Despite playing just eight games, he was a member of Melbourne's 1941 premiership team. The following week, he played in another premiership, back home in Western Australia with West Perth. He was also a regular interstate representative for Western Australia, winning a Simpson Medal for his performance in a game against South Australia in 1949 and captaining his state at the 1950 Brisbane Carnival. As

a game against South Australia in 1949 and captaining his state at the 1950 Brisbane Carnival. As coach of West Perth from 1947 to 1952, he steered his club to two premierships, in 1949 and 1951. Heal was inducted into the Australian Football Hall of Fame in 2010. He died on 15 December 2010.

text_with_error:
Ithamara Koorax is a renowned Brazilian jazz and bossa nova vocalist celebrated for her versatile voice and extensive repertoire that spans various genres, including jazz, bossa nova, samba, and MPB (Música Popular Brasileira). Born on May 28, 1965, in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, Koorax has established herself as one of the leading figures in contemporary Brazilian music, gaining international acclaim for her unique interpretations and vocal prowess.

Koorax's early exposure to music was influenced by her family's rich musical background and the vibrant cultural landscape of Brazil. She began her career in the late 1980s, quickly capturing the attention of both local and international audiences with her emotive and technically skilled performances. Her debut album, released in the early 1990s, marked the beginning of a prolific recording career that would see her collaborate with numerous distinguished artists and musicians worldwide.

Throughout her career, Ithamara Koorax has worked with an impressive array of artists, including Antonio Carlos Jobim, Luiz Bonfá, and Ron Carter, showcasing her ability to seamlessly blend traditional Brazilian sounds with global jazz influences. Her collaborations have not only enriched her musical style but also contributed to the cross-cultural exchange between Brazilian music and jazz.

Koorax's discography includes several critically acclaimed albums, which have consistently received praise for their sophisticated arrangements and Koorax's expressive vocal interpretations. Her work has been recognized with numerous awards and nominations, underscoring her status as a prominent figure in the music industry. She has been featured in prestigious venues and festivals around the world, further solidifying her reputation as an ambassador of Brazilian music on the global stage.

In addition to her performance career, Ithamara Koorax is also known for her dedication to preserving and promoting Brazilian musical heritage. She actively participates in educational initiatives and workshops, sharing her knowledge and passion with aspiring musicians and students.

Ithamara Koorax's contribution to music extends beyond her recordings and performances; she embodies the rich tradition of Brazilian music while continually exploring new artistic horizons. Her ability to transcend cultural and musical boundaries has made her a beloved figure among diverse audiences, earning her a lasting legacy in the world of jazz and bossa nova.
wiki_bio_text:
Ithamara Koorax (born 23 May 1965) is a popular Brazilian pop-jazz singer. She was born in Rio de Janeiro and has worked with such artists as Antonio Carlos Jobim, Luiz Bonfa, Ron Carter, Larry Coryell, Elizeth Cardoso, Gonzalo Rubalcaba, John McLaughlin, Sadao Watanabe, Hermeto Pascoal, Marcos Valle, Peter Scharli, Jay Berliner, Edu Lobo, Martinho da Vila, Jürgen Friedrich, Claus Ogerman, Dave Brubeck, João Donato, Dom Um Romão, Thiago de Mello, Mario Castro-Neves, Raul de Souza, Chris Conway, Eumir Deodato, Lou Volpe, Laudir de Oliveira, Rodgers Grant, Gil Goldstein, Art Farmer, Eddie Gomez, the groups Azymuth, Gazzara and Os Cariocas, the big bands Amazon and Rio Jazz Orchestra, and the symphony orchestras "Petrobras" and "Jazz Sinfonica". She has recorded solo albums for the Irma, Milestone, Mercury, EMI, JVC, King, Huk's and Motema labels, besides fourteen soundtracks for movies and TV series, and also took part in more than 200 special projects and compilations.

In 2009, "Bim Bom - The Complete Joao Gilberto Songbook," a duo session with guitarist Juarez Moreira, received rave reviews in The New York Times, Cashbox, Billboard, Jazz Hot, Jazz 'n' More, All Music Guide, and many other magazines, websites and newspapers. Another recent CD, "O Grande Amor," recorded during a European tour with the Peter Schärli Trio in 2010, was also released with critical acclaim, receiving a 4 and 1/2 star review in the May 2011 issue of Downbeat magazine and 5-star ratings in several other magazines like Jazz 'n' More. Later on, "O Grande Amor" was elected one of the "Best CDs of 2011" in the January 2012 issue of Downbeat.

Ithamara Koorax has performed in the USA, Japan, Korea and many European countries (England, France, Germany, Switzerland, Czech Republic, Finland, Bulgaria, Serbia, Portugal etc.), appearing at jazz festivals in London, Seoul, Belgrade, Funchal, Helsinki, Indijja and many other cities. Koorax has also performed classical and fusion concerts backed by symphony orchestras. Her recordings have been remixed by DJs from all over the world, including Tom Novy, Parov Stelar, Cargo, and Tetsu Shibuya/Brisa. During 2010, Ithamara performed 47 concerts in Brazil and 51 abroad, having toured Europe and Asia. In her latest Korean tour, in August 2010, Ithamara recorded an all-star project, "Arirang," alongside many pop Korean artists (like the pop group Miji) and such jazz musicians as guitarist Lee Ritenour & pianist/arranger Alan Broadbent, Diana Krall's conductor.

Koorax's latest CD, "Got to Be Real," was released in March 2012.

text_with_error:
Thomas Clayton Wolfe (October 3, 1900 – September 15, 1938) was a prominent American novelist of the early 20th century, renowned for his distinctive and autobiographical style of writing. Born in Asheville, North Carolina, Wolfe's work is characterized by its sweeping narratives and richly detailed exploration of American life. His literary contributions, though limited by his short life, have left an indelible mark on American literature.

Wolfe's early life in Asheville greatly influenced his writing, providing a vivid backdrop for his exuberant prose. He attended the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, where he developed his passion for literature and playwriting. Wolfe further honed his craft at Harvard University, studying under the tutelage of renowned playwright George Pierce Baker. Initially aspiring to be a playwright, Wolfe transitioned to novel writing, where he found his true voice.

His first novel, "Look Homeward, Angel," published in 1929, garnered significant acclaim for its lyrical intensity and its candid portrayal of a young man's tumultuous journey to self-discovery. The novel's semi-autobiographical nature and its vivid depiction of the fictional town of Altamont, based on Asheville, resonated with readers and established Wolfe as a formidable literary talent.

Wolfe's subsequent works, including "Of Time and the River" (1935), continued to explore themes of identity, ambition, and the passage of time, often blending personal experiences with broader social commentary. His writing style, characterized by intricate descriptions and emotional depth, drew comparisons to literary giants such as James Joyce and Marcel Proust.

Despite his literary success, Wolfe's career was marked by a turbulent relationship with his editor, Maxwell Perkins, of Scribner's. Perkins played a crucial role in shaping Wolfe's sprawling manuscripts into publishable form, but their collaboration was often fraught with creative tensions.

Wolfe's life was tragically cut short when he died of tuberculosis of the brain at the age of 37. Despite his brief career, his influence on subsequent generations of writers is profound, with authors such as Jack Kerouac and Ray Bradbury citing him as an inspiration. His exploration of the American experience, coupled with his innovative narrative techniques, cemented his legacy as a pioneering figure in modern American literature. Wolfe's ability to capture the essence of the human spirit continues to resonate, ensuring his place among the literary greats of the 20th century.
wiki_bio_text: Thomas Clayton Wolfe (October 3, 1900 – September 15, 1938) was a major American novelist of the early twentieth century. Wolfe wrote four lengthy novels, plus many short stories, dramatic works, and novellas. He is known for mixing highly original, poetic, rhapsodic, and impressionistic prose with autobiographical writing. His books, written and published from the 1920s to the 1940s, vividly reflect on American culture and mores of the period, albeit filtered through Wolfe's sensitive, sophisticated, and hyper-analytical perspective. He became very famous during his own lifetime. After Wolfe's death, his contemporary William Faulkner said that Wolfe may have had the best talent of their generation. Wolfe's influence extends to the writings of famous Beat writer Jack Kerouac, authors Ray Bradbury and Philip Roth, among others. He remains one of the most important writers in modern American literature, as he was one of the first masters of autobiographical fiction. He is considered North Carolina's most famous writer.
