Iwakuma is a Japanese surname that is most notably associated with Hisashi Iwakuma, a professional baseball pitcher. Born on April 12, 1981, in Higashiyamato, Tokyo, Japan, Hisashi Iwakuma has made significant contributions to the sport both in Japan and the United States. He began his professional career in Nippon Professional Baseball (NPB) with the Osaka Kintetsu Buffaloes in 2000. Over the years, Iwakuma established himself as a formidable pitcher, earning accolades such as the Pacific League MVP in 2008 while playing for the Tohoku Rakuten Golden Eagles.

In 2012, Iwakuma transitioned to Major League Baseball (MLB) in the United States, signing with the Seattle Mariners. His tenure with the Mariners was marked by consistent performances, including a no-hitter game against the Baltimore Orioles on August 12, 2015. This achievement made him only the second Japanese pitcher in MLB history to throw a no-hitter. Iwakuma's pitching style is characterized by his exceptional control and ability to induce ground balls, making him a valuable asset to his teams.

Throughout his career, Iwakuma has been recognized for his sportsmanship and dedication to the game. Despite facing injuries that impacted his playing time, he remained a respected figure in baseball circles. After retiring from professional play, Iwakuma continued to contribute to the sport, taking on roles such as a special assignment coach for the Mariners, where he shared his expertise and experience with younger players.

Iwakuma's legacy extends beyond his on-field achievements, as he is also known for his charitable work and efforts to promote baseball in Japan and internationally. His career serves as an inspiration to aspiring athletes, demonstrating the importance of perseverance, skill, and adaptability in achieving success at the highest levels of professional sports.
wiki_bio_text: Iwakuma made his professional debut with the Buffaloes in 2000. He was named an NPB All-Star in 2003 and 2004, and played in the 2004 Athens Olympics. He joined the Eagles in 2005. As the Eagles' reigning staff ace, Iwakuma won the Eiji Sawamura Award in 2005, and was also an NPB All-Star that year. He appeared in the 2009 World Baseball Classic for the Japanese national team. Iwakuma was posted to Major League Baseball after the 2010 season, but he failed to come to an agreement with the winning bidder. After the 2011 season, Iwakuma signed with the Mariners. He was an MLB All-Star in 2013, as well as the third-place finisher for the 2013 American League Cy Young Award. On August 12, 2015, Iwakuma became the second Japanese player ever to pitch a no-hitter in Major League Baseball (joining Hideo Nomo, who threw two), throwing a three-walk, seven-strikeout 3-0 win over the Baltimore Orioles at Safeco Field. It was also his first career complete game, and the Mariners' fifth no-hitter in team history.

Virginia Hilda Brunette Maxwell Bottomley, Baroness Bottomley of Nettlestone, born on March 12, 1948, is a prominent British Conservative Party politician and life peer. She served as a Member of Parliament (MP) for South West Surrey from 1984 to 2005 and held several significant ministerial positions during her political career. Bottomley is particularly noted for her roles as Secretary of State for Health from 1992 to 1995 and Secretary of State for National Heritage from 1995 to 1997 under Prime Minister John Major.

Educated at the University of Essex and the London School of Economics, Bottomley began her career as a social worker and magistrate before entering politics. Her background in social work informed her approach to health and social policy, emphasizing community care and mental health services. As Health Secretary, she oversaw the implementation of the National Health Service and Community Care Act 1990, which aimed to improve the efficiency and quality of healthcare delivery in the UK.

In 1995, Bottomley transitioned to the role of Secretary of State for National Heritage, where she was responsible for overseeing the arts, broadcasting, and cultural heritage sectors. Her tenure was marked by efforts to increase public access to cultural institutions and support for the burgeoning digital media landscape.

After leaving the House of Commons in 2005, Bottomley was elevated to the House of Lords, where she continues to contribute to public life as a life peer. Beyond her political career, she has been involved in various charitable and corporate endeavors, including serving on the boards of several major companies and non-profit organizations.

Baroness Bottomley's contributions to public service have been recognized with numerous honors, reflecting her impact on British politics and society. Her career is characterized by a commitment to public welfare, cultural enrichment, and the modernization of public services.
wiki_bio_text: Virginia Hilda Brunette Maxwell Bottomley, Baroness Bottomley of Nettlestone, PC, DL (née Garnett, born 12 March 1948) is a British Conservative Party politician. She was a Member of Parliament (MP) in the House of Commons from 1984 to 2005. She was raised to the peerage in 2005. Considered to be a "One Nation Conservative", Bottomley is a life member of the Tory Reform Group. She was a member of the Supervisory Board of Akzo Nobel NV from 2000–12, an NED on Bupa 2007–2013 and currently Smith and Nephew, and a trustee of The Economist newspaper. As part of her pro-bono activities, Virginia is Chancellor of the University of Hull and Governor of the London School of Economics. She is a member of the UK Advisory Council of the International Chamber of Commerce. She has been Chair of the Board Practice at executive head-hunting firm Odgers Berndtson since 2000.

John Liscio was a prominent American financial journalist and analyst, renowned for his insightful commentary on economic trends and financial markets. He gained recognition as the founder and publisher of The Liscio Report, an influential newsletter that provided in-depth analysis and forecasts on economic indicators and market conditions. Liscio's work was highly regarded for its rigorous analysis and data-driven approach, appealing to a wide range of subscribers, including investors, economists, and policymakers.

Liscio's career in financial journalism was marked by his keen ability to interpret complex economic data and present it in a comprehensible manner for both professional and lay audiences. He began his career at Barron's, a leading financial publication, where he honed his skills in analyzing market trends and writing incisive reports. During his tenure at Barron's, Liscio developed a reputation for his ability to predict economic shifts, earning the respect of peers and readers alike.

In 1992, Liscio launched The Liscio Report, which quickly became a must-read for those interested in real-time economic analysis. The newsletter was particularly noted for its focus on state and local tax receipts as a real-time indicator of economic activity, a novel approach at the time. Liscio's analysis often provided an early warning for economic downturns, making his insights invaluable for those looking to navigate the complexities of financial markets.

Throughout his career, Liscio was a frequent commentator on economic issues, contributing to various media outlets and participating in industry conferences. His work remained influential even after his untimely passing, with The Liscio Report continuing under the stewardship of his colleagues, maintaining the legacy of his analytical rigor and insightful commentary.

John Liscio's contributions to financial journalism and economic analysis left an enduring impact on the field, providing a model for data-driven economic forecasting and commentary. His innovative use of tax receipt data as an economic indicator remains a significant part of his legacy, inspiring future generations of financial analysts and journalists to explore new methodologies in economic analysis.
wiki_bio_text: John Liscio (1949 - November 29, 2000) was an American journalist covering finance and the economy, as well as an independent financial analyst. He was the founder of the influential bond market newsletter, "The Liscio Report". Liscio was born to Armand and Josephine Liscio in Manhattan and matriculated from Fordham Preparatory School in the Bronx to Fordham University, where he earned a bachelor's degree. He served in the Marine Corps before becoming a financial writer and analyst in the late 1970s. He was a senior editor at "U.S. News & World Report" and worked at "Barron's" in the late 1980s into the early 1990s. In 1992, he started "The Liscio Report", a financial newsletter that became influential on Wall Street and especially so among bond traders. Upon his death in 2000, the newsletter was continued by trusted associates Doug Henwood and Phillipa Dunne. Liscio died, aged 51, on November 29, 2000, at Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan from liver and kidney failure complications due to a hepatitis C infection. He was survived by his wife, Frances Pelzman Liscio, a humor writer, two preadolescent children, both his parents, and a sister.

John Vallely is a former American professional basketball player known for his contributions to the sport during the late 1960s and early 1970s. Born on June 3, 1948, in Balboa Island, California, Vallely rose to prominence as a standout guard at the University of California, Los Angeles (UCLA), where he played under the legendary coach John Wooden. During his collegiate career, Vallely was instrumental in helping the UCLA Bruins secure two NCAA championships in 1969 and 1970, showcasing his skills as a reliable scorer and playmaker.

Vallely's success at UCLA led to his selection in the first round of the 1970 NBA Draft by the Atlanta Hawks. He played two seasons in the National Basketball Association (NBA), splitting his time between the Hawks and the Houston Rockets. Although his professional career was relatively brief, Vallely left a lasting impact on the court with his tenacity and basketball IQ.

After retiring from professional basketball, Vallely transitioned into a successful business career and became actively involved in philanthropic efforts. He is particularly noted for his work with cancer research and support organizations, inspired by his personal battle with non-Hodgkin's lymphoma. Vallely's dedication to community service and his contributions to the sport have earned him recognition beyond his playing days.

John Vallely's legacy is marked by his achievements as a collegiate athlete, his brief yet impactful professional career, and his ongoing commitment to making a difference in the lives of others through his charitable endeavors.
wiki_bio_text:
John Vallely (born October 3, 1948) is a retired American basketball player from Balboa Island, Newport Beach, California. He played for the UCLA Bruins and in the National Basketball Association. He attended Corona del Mar High School, where he was a guard turned forward. He was selected to the All California Interscholastic Federation team and twice captured All Irvine League honors. As a 6'2" forward for Orange Coast College, Vallely averaged 26 points per game and broke 18 scoring records. He was selected a Junior College All American. He dribbled with his left hand and shot with his right hand, and was especially good at shooting an outside jump shot.

Vallely was an integral member of the Bruins' backcourt after transferring from Orange Coast College in 1968. He was quick to make the transition from forward to guard at UCLA. In his first season, he was the Bruins' third leading scorer (12.9 p.p.g.) and adapted smoothly to head coach John Wooden's "attack and gamble offense". He was a member of the UCLA teams that won national titles in the 1969 NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Tournament and the 1970 NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Tournament. Vallely majored in economics at UCLA and had a 3.36 grade point average as a junior. He was selected to the twelve-man 1968 Olympic trials team coached by Jerry Tarkanian which competed in Albuquerque, New Mexico.

He was taken by the Atlanta Hawks in the first round of the 1970 NBA Draft. He sat on the bench much of the time, playing behind Pete Maravich, Lou Hudson, Walt Hazzard, and Herm Gilliam. Vallely was acquired by the Houston Rockets in November 1971 along with 6'7" forward Jim Davis.

Johannes Andreas August Grabau (March 18, 1804 – June 2, 1879) was a prominent German-American Lutheran pastor and theologian, recognized for his significant influence on the development of Lutheranism in the United States during the 19th century. Born in Olvenstedt, near Magdeburg, in the Kingdom of Prussia, Grabau was educated at the University of Halle, where he studied theology. Ordained in 1829, he initially served as a pastor in Erfurt. His tenure in Prussia was marked by conflict with the Prussian Union of Churches, which sought to merge Lutheran and Reformed traditions, prompting his staunch defense of traditional Lutheran doctrine.

In 1839, amid increasing religious persecution under King Frederick William III's policies, Grabau emigrated to the United States with a group of like-minded Lutherans seeking religious freedom. They settled in Buffalo, New York, where Grabau established the Buffalo Synod, formally known as the Synod of the Lutheran Church Emigrants from Prussia. This synod became a bastion for confessional Lutheranism, adhering strictly to the Lutheran Confessions and the Unaltered Augsburg Confession.

Grabau's leadership was characterized by his unwavering commitment to orthodox Lutheran theology and ecclesiastical practices. He was a vocal critic of the American Lutheran Church's tendency toward theological liberalism and unionism, which he believed compromised doctrinal purity. His theological conservatism often led to tensions with other Lutheran groups and leaders, most notably with the Missouri Synod led by C. F. W. Walther, resulting in what became known as the "Grabau-Walther controversy."

Throughout his career, Grabau emphasized the importance of proper ecclesiastical order, the sacraments, and pastoral authority. He authored several theological works and extensive correspondence aimed at defending his views and guiding his followers. His influence extended beyond Buffalo, as he assisted in the establishment of numerous congregations across the northeastern United States and parts of Canada.

Johannes Andreas August Grabau's legacy is marked by his steadfast dedication to maintaining confessional Lutheranism amidst a rapidly changing religious landscape. His efforts to preserve traditional Lutheran practices and beliefs contributed significantly to the shaping of Lutheran identity in North America. Despite the controversies surrounding his leadership style and theological positions, Grabau remains a pivotal figure in the history of American Lutheranism, remembered for his commitment to faith and doctrine.
wiki_bio_text: Johannes Andreas August Grabau (March 18, 1804 - June 2, 1879) was an influential German-American Old Lutheran pastor and theologian. He is usually mentioned as J.A.A. Grabau. Grabau was born in Olvenstedt, Prussia (now a part of Greater Magdeburg, Germany). He was the son of Johann Andreas Grabau and Anna Dorothea Jericho. Grabau was educated at the grammar school in Olvenstedt (1809 - 1818), the Magdeburg Gymnasium (1818 - 1825), and at the University of Halle (1825 - 1829). After three years as a teacher in Magdeburg and Sachsa bei Nordhausen, Grabau was ordained and installed as pastor of St. Andrew's Church in Erfurt in June 1834. Grabau was jailed twice for refusing to use the Prussian Union agenda and was permitted to immigrate to America in summer 1839 with members of Lutheran congregations in Erfurt and Magdeburg. They settled in Buffalo, New York, where he served as pastor of a Lutheran congregation for 40 years. On July 15, 1845, along with four pastors, Grabau founded "The Synod of the Lutheran Church Emigrated from Prussia" (German: "Synode der aus Preussen ausgewanderten lutherischen Kirche"), which became known as "The Buffalo Synod". Grabau also founded the Martin Luther College in Buffalo. Grabau retained control of the Martin Luther College and remained as its rector. The official organ of Grabau's synod after 1866 was "Die Wachende Kirche", under his editorship. Grabau was married on July 15, 1834, to Christine Sophia Burgraf, the daughter of Johann Andreas Burggraf and Friedericke Louise Elizabeth Beulke. They had at least three children: Johann, Wilhelm, and Beata. Grabau died on June 2, 1879 in Buffalo, New York, shortly before the 40th anniversary of his arrival in the United States.

Guðlaugur Þór Þórðarson (born December 19, 1967) is an Icelandic politician who has played a significant role in the country's political landscape. A member of the Independence Party, Guðlaugur has held various key positions in Iceland's government, demonstrating a strong influence in shaping domestic and international policies. Educated at the University of Iceland, he has a background in political science, which has informed his approach to governance and policy-making.

Guðlaugur Þór Þórðarson first entered the Icelandic political scene as a member of the Althing, Iceland's national parliament, in 2003. He has been re-elected multiple times, underscoring his enduring popularity and the trust placed in him by his constituents. Known for his dedication to public service, Guðlaugur has focused on a range of issues, including economic reform, environmental sustainability, and foreign affairs.

One of Guðlaugur's most notable roles was serving as Iceland's Minister for Foreign Affairs from 2017 to 2021. During his tenure, he worked to strengthen Iceland's diplomatic relations, particularly within the framework of the Nordic Council and with the European Union, while also advocating for human rights and sustainable development on the global stage. His leadership in this capacity was marked by efforts to enhance Iceland's influence in international forums and to promote global cooperation on climate change, a critical issue for the island nation.

In addition to his role in foreign affairs, Guðlaugur has been involved in various other governmental functions, contributing to the discourse on economic policies and national infrastructure projects. His approach often emphasizes the importance of Iceland's unique cultural and natural heritage, advocating for policies that balance economic growth with environmental protection.

Throughout his career, Guðlaugur Þór Þórðarson has been recognized for his pragmatic yet forward-thinking approach to governance. His ability to navigate complex political landscapes and his commitment to his country's welfare have made him a prominent figure in Icelandic politics. His contributions continue to shape the future of Iceland, as he remains actively engaged in addressing the challenges and opportunities facing the nation in an increasingly interconnected world.
wiki_bio_text: Guðlaugur Þór Þórðarson (born 19 December 1967) is an Icelandic politician. He has been a member of the Althing (Iceland's parliament) for the Independence Party since 2003 and served as the Minister of Health from 24 May 2007 to 1 February 2009. He is the first MP of the Reykjavík North constituency, after beating the Minister of Justice and Ecclesiastical Affairs, Björn Bjarnason, in the primary election. Guðlaugur graduated with a BA degree in political sciences from the University of Iceland in 1996. He is married to Ágústa Johnson, and is the father of two children. Guðlaugur started his involvement in the Independence Party in 1987 when he was elected to the board of the National Youth Organisation of the Independence Party, in which he served until 1997; of which he was Vice Chairman from 1989 to 1993 and Chairman from 1993 to 1997. He was then elected to the Reykjavík City Council in 1998 and sat two four-year terms there. He sat on the Parliamentary Committee on Welfare Issues from 2003 to 2006, the Committee on Fisheries from 2003 to 2007, and the Committee on the Environment from 2003 to 2007 (Chairman from 2004 to 2007).

Laurie Lévesque is a distinguished academic and researcher known for her contributions to the field of organizational behavior and management. She is a professor at Bentley University, where she has been instrumental in advancing the understanding of workplace dynamics and leadership. Lévesque's research primarily focuses on the intersection of technology and human behavior in organizational settings, exploring how digital tools and platforms influence team collaboration, decision-making, and employee engagement.

Lévesque earned her Ph.D. in Organizational Behavior from the University of California, Berkeley, where she developed a keen interest in the psychological aspects of work environments. Her academic journey has been marked by a commitment to bridging theory and practice, which is evident in her numerous publications in leading management journals. Her work often emphasizes the importance of adaptive leadership and the role of emotional intelligence in navigating complex organizational challenges.

In addition to her research, Lévesque is highly regarded for her teaching and mentorship. She has received several awards for her innovative teaching methods, which incorporate experiential learning and real-world applications. Her courses are popular among students for their engaging content and practical relevance, preparing future leaders to thrive in diverse and dynamic business environments.

Lévesque is also an active participant in various professional organizations, contributing to the development of best practices in management education and research. Her insights are frequently sought by industry leaders and policymakers, reflecting her status as a thought leader in her field. Through her work, Laurie Lévesque continues to influence the way organizations understand and implement effective management strategies in the digital age.
wiki_bio_text:
Laurier Lévesque (October 13, 1929 - September 2005) was a Canadian educator and politician in the province of New Brunswick. A graduate of St. Joseph's College in Memramcook and the New Brunswick Teachers' College in Fredericton, Lévesque taught school before entering political life. A resident of Edmundston, New Brunswick, he was first elected to the Legislative Assembly in the 1960 New Brunswick general election as a Liberal Party candidate for one of the three seats for Madawaska County. He was reelected in 1963, 1967, and 1970. In the 1974 election, he lost by 95 votes to the Progressive Conservative candidate Jean-Pierre Ouellet in the newly created riding of Madawaska-les-Lacs. Without the Parti Acadien contesting the riding, Lévesque may have won; the Parti Acadien received 99 votes, ones that are generally accepted as being traditional Liberal supporters. Lévesque attempted a political comeback in the City of Edmundston riding in 1982 but lost to Jean-Maurice Simard.

As a member of the Legislative Assembly in the government of Premier Louis Robichaud, Lévesque was an ardent defender of Francophone rights and was one of the first members to give his speeches in the Assembly in the French language. Out of politics, in 1990 the Government of Canada appointed him to diplomatic missions abroad which organized and supervised democratic elections in 10 African countries, in two countries from the former Soviet Union, as well as in Bosnia and Herzegovina.

Michael Joseph "Micky" Moody (born 30 August 1950) is an English guitarist renowned for his contributions to the rock and blues genres. He gained prominence as a key member of the rock band Whitesnake, playing a pivotal role in shaping the band's distinctive sound during its formative years. Moody's musical journey began in the vibrant rock scene of the late 1960s and early 1970s, where he honed his skills and developed a signature slide guitar style that would become his trademark.

Moody was born in Middlesbrough, England, and his early exposure to music came from his family's passion for the art. He was inspired by blues legends such as Muddy Waters and Elmore James, which greatly influenced his musical direction. His professional career started with the band Tramline in the late 1960s, followed by stints with Juicy Lucy and Snafu, where he further developed his craft and gained recognition for his guitar prowess.

In 1978, Moody co-founded Whitesnake with former Deep Purple vocalist David Coverdale. The band quickly rose to fame, becoming one of the leading acts in the hard rock scene of the late 1970s and early 1980s. Moody's guitar work, characterized by its fluidity and emotional depth, was instrumental in crafting hits such as "Fool for Your Loving" and "Walking in the Shadow of the Blues." His tenure with Whitesnake, which lasted until 1983, left an indelible mark on the band's legacy and contributed significantly to their commercial success.

After leaving Whitesnake, Moody pursued a diverse range of musical projects, showcasing his versatility and enduring passion for music. He collaborated with various artists and bands, including Frankie Miller, Roger Chapman, and Eric Burdon, and was involved in numerous recording sessions and live performances. Moody also explored a successful solo career, releasing albums that highlighted his wide-ranging influences and exceptional guitar skills.

Aside from his musical endeavors, Moody has been involved in writing and composing, contributing to film and television soundtracks. His autobiography, "Snakes and Ladders," offers an insightful account of his life and career, providing fans and music enthusiasts with a glimpse into his experiences in the rock and blues worlds.

Micky Moody remains a respected figure in the music industry, celebrated for his talent, creativity, and contributions to rock and blues music. His influence continues to resonate with new generations of musicians and fans alike.
wiki_bio_text:
Michael Joseph "Micky" Moody (born 30 August 1950) is an English guitarist, and a former member of the rock bands Juicy Lucy and Whitesnake. He was also a founder-member of Snafu. Together with his former Whitesnake colleague Bernie Marsden, he founded the Moody Marsden Band, and later, The Snakes, having previously collaborated with unofficial fifth Status Quo member Bob Young in Young & Moody. Along with Marsden and ex-Whitesnake bassist Neil Murray, he formed Company of Snakes and M3 Classic Whitesnake, with which they mainly performed early Whitesnake songs. From 2010, he has been working with Murray, guitarist Laurie Wisefield, drummer Harry James, singer Chris Ousey, and keyboard player Michael Bramwell in Monsters of British Rock, which has morphed into Snakecharmer with Adam Wakeman on keyboards. Besides this, Moody has also toured with Roger Chapman, Frankie Miller, and Chris Farlowe. He has also performed live alongside the likes of Eric Clapton, Alvin Lee, Mick Taylor, Bruce Dickinson, Sam Brown, Gary Brooker, Suggs, Dennis Locorriere, Paul Jones, P.P. Arnold, James Hunter, Rick Wakeman, Jon Lord, Newton Faulkner, Uriah Heep, Alice Cooper, Mark King, Alfie Boe, Sandi Thom, Brian Auger, Paul Weller, Eric Bibb, Meat Loaf, Boy George, Elkie Brooks, Nona Hendryx, Mud Morganfield, and one of his early guitar heroes, Duane Eddy.

Since 2000, he has released several solo albums: "I Eat Them for Breakfast" (2000), "Don't Blame Me" (2006), "Acoustic Journeyman" (2007), and "Electric Journeyman" (2009). A versatile guitarist, Moody has been an active session musician, and his own website lists over 100 albums to which he has contributed musically. 2006 saw the release of the autobiographical "Playing with Trumpets – A Rock 'n' Roll Apprenticeship", a memoir about his early days on the music scene. His library music has been featured on such TV programmes as "Waking the Dead", "Bo' Selecta!", "America's Next Top Model", "How to Look Good Naked", "Top Gear", "Horizon", "Jersey Shore", "Mad Men", "Wife Swap", and "Paul Hollywood's Bread".

splitted_wiki: Michael Joseph "Micky" Moody (born 30 August 1950) is an English guitarist, and a former member of the rock bands Juicy Lucy and Whitesnake. He was also a founder-member of Snafu. Together with his former Whitesnake colleague Bernie Marsden, he founded the Moody Marsden Band, and later, The Snakes, having previously collaborated with unofficial fifth Status Quo member Bob Young in Young & Moody. Along with Marsden and ex-Whitesnake bassist Neil Murray, he formed Company of Snakes and M3 Classic

with Marsden and ex-Whitesnake bassist Neil Murray, he formed Company of Snakes and M3 Classic Whitesnake, with which they mainly performed early Whitesnake songs. From 2010, he has been working with Murray, guitarist Laurie Wisefield, drummer Harry James, singer Chris Ousey, and keyboard player Michael Bramwell in Monsters of British Rock, which has morphed into Snakecharmer with Adam Wakeman on keyboards. Besides this, Moody has also toured with Roger Chapman, Frankie Miller, and Chris

on keyboards. Besides this, Moody has also toured with Roger Chapman, Frankie Miller, and Chris Farlowe. He has also performed live alongside the likes of Eric Clapton, Alvin Lee, Mick Taylor, Bruce Dickinson, Sam Brown, Gary Brooker, Suggs, Dennis Locorriere, Paul Jones, P.P. Arnold, James Hunter, Rick Wakeman, Jon Lord, Newton Faulkner, Uriah Heep, Alice Cooper, Mark King, Alfie Boe, Sandi Thom, Brian Auger, Paul Weller, Eric Bibb, Meat Loaf, Boy George, Elkie Brooks, Nona Hendryx, Mud
Thom, Brian Auger, Paul Weller, Eric Bibb, Meat Loaf, Boy George, Elkie Brooks, Nona Hendryx, Mud Morganfield, and one of his early guitar heroes, Duane Eddy.

Since 2000, he has released several solo albums: "I Eat Them for Breakfast" (2000), "Don't Blame Me" (2006), "Acoustic Journeyman" (2007), and "Electric Journeyman" (2009). A versatile guitarist, Moody has been an active session musician, and his own website lists over 100 albums to which he has contributed musically. 2006 saw the release of the autobiographical "Playing with Trumpets – A Rock 'n' Roll Apprenticeship", a memoir about his early days on the music scene. His library music has been

Roll Apprenticeship", a memoir about his early days on the music scene. His library music has been featured on such TV programmes as "Waking the Dead", "Bo' Selecta!", "America's Next Top Model", "How to Look Good Naked", "Top Gear", "Horizon", "Jersey Shore", "Mad Men", "Wife Swap", and "Paul Hollywood's Bread".

Baba Gündüz Kılıç (1919 – 17 May 1980) was a prominent Turkish football player and manager, widely regarded as one of the most influential figures in Turkish football history. Born in Istanbul, Kılıç began his football career in the late 1930s, quickly establishing himself as a talented and versatile midfielder. His playing career, most notably with Galatasaray S.K., was distinguished by his exceptional leadership qualities and deep understanding of the game.

Kılıç's impact on Turkish football extended far beyond his playing days. After retiring as a player, he transitioned seamlessly into management, where his strategic acumen and innovative coaching methods earned him the affectionate nickname "Baba" (Father) among players and fans alike. His tenure as the manager of Galatasaray was marked by significant success, as he led the team to multiple national championships and helped lay the foundation for the club's future successes.

Renowned for his tactical expertise and ability to nurture young talent, Kılıç was instrumental in the development of numerous players who would go on to make substantial contributions to Turkish football. His emphasis on discipline, teamwork, and strategic planning revolutionized the way football was played and managed in Turkey, setting new standards for professionalism and excellence.

Kılıç's contributions to football were recognized not only by his club but also by the broader Turkish sporting community. His legacy is celebrated for having transformed Galatasaray into a powerhouse in Turkish football and for his role in popularizing the sport across the nation. Beyond his technical and tactical contributions, Kılıç was admired for his integrity, sportsmanship, and dedication to the growth of football, both on and off the field.

Throughout his career, Baba Gündüz Kılıç remained a beloved figure in Turkish sports, embodying the spirit of perseverance and passion. His influence continues to be felt in modern Turkish football, where his teachings and philosophies remain integral to the training and development of future generations. Gündüz Kılıç's life and career left an indelible mark on the history of Turkish sports, earning him a revered place among the legends of the game. His passing in 1980 was a significant loss to the football community, but his legacy endures through the countless players, coaches, and fans who were inspired by his remarkable contributions to the sport.
wiki_bio_text:
Baba Gündüz Kılıç (1918-1980) was a Turkish football player and coach. He was the son of Ali Kılıç and the brother of Altemur Kılıç. Born in 1918 in Istanbul, Gündüz Kılıç attended Galatasaray Lycee and then started his football career as a center forward with Galatasaray SK. He was strong, big, well-educated, sophisticated, charismatic, charming, and hungry for success. He never looked flashy, yet was never boring. Kılıç was the mastermind behind the rise of Turkish football, schooling football players that would become respectable managers after their career. He took a break from his career in 1938, moving to Germany for a university education. When he returned to Turkey, he again wore the Galatasaray shirt and won two league championships with the team. Kılıç, who played 11 matches with the Turkey national football team, played for Galatasaray until 1953, except for when he played for Ankara Demirspor during his national service military obligation. His five goals against Beşiktaş JK are still a record for all three Istanbulian derbies. His five goals were scored in the 43rd (1-1), 58th (4-1), 73rd (5-2), 76th (6-2), and 89th (9-2).

The "Gündüz Kılıç Revolution" started early one morning at Galatasaray in 1952, when he hung his uniform in his locker and put on his coaching suit and whistle without looking back. Once the captain of the Galatasaray team, Gündüz Kılıç coached his former teammates and the bright young talents he added to the squad. He led his team to several championships after eighteen years without a championship between 1934 and 1952. He also transferred Turkish superstar Metin Oktay to the team. Under Kılıç, Galatasaray reached the quarter-finals of the European Cup, with the AC Milan side of Nereo Rocco ending their run. Every Galatasaray player, student, or supporter had found an exemplary man in Gündüz Kılıç: a man who performed so well, motivated so well, educated so well, and brought out the very best in every single person he ever worked with. A true gentleman both on and off the field, Gündüz Kılıç helped Galatasaray to reach new targets. Under his leadership, Galatasaray won numerous championships, Turkish Cup titles, and international matches. His visionary coaching style and strong communication skills were to be the backbone of Turkish coaching for many years to come.

The player, whose nickname was "Father", died in New York City, USA on 17 May 1980. His body was transferred to Istanbul and was interred at the Aşiyan Asri Cemetery.

text_with_error:
Michael Replogle is an American civil engineer and transportation policy expert known for his pioneering work in sustainable and equitable transportation planning. With a career spanning over four decades, Replogle has significantly influenced transportation policy at both national and international levels. He is a co-founder and managing director for policy at the Institute for Transportation and Development Policy (ITDP), an organization dedicated to promoting sustainable and equitable transportation solutions in urban centers worldwide.

Replogle's career began in the 1980s when he worked with various organizations to integrate environmental considerations into transportation planning. He played a crucial role in developing policies that advocate for reduced automotive dependency and increased support for public transit, cycling, and pedestrian infrastructure. His work has been instrumental in advancing the concept of "smart growth" and advocating for transportation systems that are not only efficient but also environmentally sustainable and socially inclusive.

He has served in various capacities with influential organizations and governmental bodies. From 2015 to 2017, Replogle was the Deputy Commissioner for Policy at the New York City Department of Transportation, where he was involved in key initiatives to modernize the city's transportation infrastructure and improve traffic safety. His leadership contributed to the implementation of Vision Zero, a program aimed at eliminating traffic fatalities and severe injuries.

In addition to his work in New York City, Replogle has been a consultant for numerous cities and countries, offering his expertise on sustainable transportation systems. His contributions have extended to global initiatives, including advising the United Nations and the World Bank on transportation and climate change issues.

Replogle's educational background includes a Bachelor of Science in Civil Engineering and a Master of Science in Civil and Urban Engineering, both from the University of Pennsylvania. His academic training laid the foundation for his technical prowess and innovative approaches in addressing complex transportation challenges.

Throughout his career, Michael Replogle has received numerous accolades for his contributions to sustainable transportation. His work continues to influence policymakers, urban planners, and civil society organizations working towards creating more livable and resilient urban environments. As an advocate for integrated transportation systems, Replogle remains a key figure in the global movement towards achieving sustainable urban mobility.
wiki_bio_text: Michael Replogle is an internationally recognized expert in the field of sustainable transport. He co-founded the Institute for Transportation and Development Policy (ITDP) in 1985, a non-profit organization that promotes environmentally sustainable and equitable transportation projects and policies worldwide, as well as Bikes Not Bombs in 1984. He was the President of ITDP from 1985-1992 and 1998-2009, and Managing Director of ITDP from 2009-2015. His seminal 1987 paper on sustainable transport was the first to define the term. Replogle co-founded the Partnership on Sustainable, Low Carbon Transport (SLOCAT) in 2009. As Transportation Director of the Environmental Defense Fund from 1992-2009, he influenced U.S. federal transportation and environmental legislation and regulations, frequently testifying in the U.S. Congress. He has advised on metropolitan transportation plans and policies in Washington, Baltimore, New York, Denver, Atlanta, Portland (OR), Mexico City, Beijing, and other areas to promote more integrated transportation and land use planning, public transportation, sound transport pricing, and transportation system management and operations. He managed integrated transport and land use planning and modeling for Montgomery County, Maryland from 1983-1992. He was a member of the Advisory Committee for the United Nations Centre for Regional Development and an active Emeritus Member of the Transportation Research Board Committee on Transportation in the Developing Countries, which he helped found. He has been a long-time advisor to the U.S. Department of Transportation (DOT), most recently through its Advisory Committees on Transportation Statistics and Intelligent Transportation and Travel Modeling. He served on the World Economic Forum Global Agenda Council on the Future of Transportation. Replogle received an M.E.S. and Honor B.E.S. in Civil and Urban Engineering and an Honor Bachelor of Arts in Sociology, all from the University of Pennsylvania. Replogle is the author of a book on access to public transportation, several hundred magazine articles, and dozens of journal articles and reports.

William John Burke (1902 – April 20, 1972) was a prominent American professional golfer during the early to mid-20th century. Born in Naugatuck, Connecticut, Burke became known for his consistent performance on the PGA Tour, where he was active primarily in the 1920s and 1930s. He is best remembered for his remarkable victory at the 1931 U.S. Open, one of the four major championships in professional golf.

Burke's career in golf began in earnest during the 1920s, a period when the sport was gaining popularity in the United States. His early years on the tour were marked by steady improvement and a growing reputation for his skillful play and sportsmanship. Burke's breakthrough came in 1931 when he clinched the U.S. Open title at Inverness Club in Toledo, Ohio. The victory was achieved after a dramatic playoff against George Von Elm, marking the pinnacle of Burke's professional career. This win cemented his status as one of the leading golfers of his era.

Throughout his career, Burke was known for his calm demeanor and strategic approach to the game. His ability to maintain composure under pressure was particularly noted during his U.S. Open triumph, where he demonstrated exceptional skill and tenacity. Although Burke did not amass a large number of tour victories, his U.S. Open win and several strong performances in other tournaments ensured his place in golf history.

After retiring from active competition, Burke continued to contribute to the sport as a club professional and instructor, sharing his knowledge and passion for golf with future generations. His legacy is remembered not only for his major championship victory but also for his role in promoting and developing the game in the United States during a formative period.

Burke passed away on April 20, 1972, leaving behind a legacy of excellence and dedication to the sport of golf. His achievements on the course and contributions off it are commemorated by golf historians and enthusiasts who recognize his impact on the game. Despite the passage of time, Burke's story remains an inspiring chapter in the history of American golf, reflecting the spirit and challenges of professional golf during the early 20th century.
wiki_bio_text: William John Burke (Polonized as Burkeauskas; December 14, 1902 – April 19, 1972) was a prominent Lithuanian-American professional golfer of the 1920s and 1930s. Burke was born in Naugatuck, Connecticut. His greatest season was 1931, when he won the U.S. Open, reached the semi-finals of the PGA Championship, and won four events on the professional circuit, plus appeared on the Ryder Cup team where he was undefeated in two matches. He was also selected for the 1933 Ryder Cup team, but not before some agitation by Gene Sarazen was done on his behalf. Burke won his only match in the 1933 competition. Burke's 1931 U.S. Open win came in a marathon playoff. He and George Von Elm were tied at 292 (8-over-par) after regulation play. They played a 36-hole playoff the next day and tied again at 149 (7-over-par). The following day they played 36 more holes and Burke emerged victorious, 148 to 149. Throughout Burke's golf career, he used an unorthodox grip due to the loss of two fingers on his left hand. In 2005, Burke was inducted into the National Polish-American Sports Hall of Fame. Burke died in Clearwater, Florida.

splitted_wiki: William John Burke (Polonized as Burkeauskas; December 14, 1902 – April 19, 1972) was a prominent Lithuanian-American professional golfer of the 1920s and 1930s. Burke was born in Naugatuck, Connecticut. His greatest season was 1931, when he won the U.S. Open, reached the semi-finals of the PGA Championship, and won four events on the professional circuit, plus appeared on the Ryder Cup team where he was undefeated in two matches. He was also selected for the 1933 Ryder Cup team, but not before

he was undefeated in two matches. He was also selected for the 1933 Ryder Cup team, but not before some agitation by Gene Sarazen was done on his behalf. Burke won his only match in the 1933 competition. Burke's 1931 U.S. Open win came in a marathon playoff. He and George Von Elm were tied at 292 (8-over-par) after regulation play. They played a 36-hole playoff the next day and tied again at 149 (7-over-par). The following day they played 36 more holes and Burke emerged victorious, 148 to 149.

(7-over-par). The following day they played 36 more holes and Burke emerged victorious, 148 to 149. Throughout Burke's golf career, he used an unorthodox grip due to the loss of two fingers on his left hand. In 2005, Burke was inducted into the National Polish-American Sports Hall of Fame. Burke died in Clearwater, Florida.

text_with_error:
Ted Childs is a prominent American diversity advocate and former corporate executive, best known for his pioneering work in advancing workplace diversity and inclusion. Throughout his career, Childs has been instrumental in shaping policies and practices that promote equality and diversity within corporate environments.

Born in the mid-20th century, Childs embarked on a career that would see him become a leading voice in diversity advocacy. He joined IBM in 1967, where he would spend over three decades, eventually rising to the position of Vice President of Global Workforce Diversity. During his tenure at IBM, Childs played a crucial role in developing and implementing diversity initiatives that not only transformed the company's workforce but also set a precedent for other corporations. His efforts were pivotal in creating a more inclusive workplace culture, which emphasized the importance of embracing diverse perspectives and backgrounds.

Childs' work at IBM included the establishment of various employee resource groups, which provided support and advocacy for minority employees and encouraged cross-cultural understanding. He was also a key figure in the development of IBM's global diversity strategy, which sought to integrate diversity into every aspect of the company's operations, from recruitment and retention to product development and marketing.

Beyond his corporate achievements, Ted Childs has been a sought-after speaker and consultant on diversity issues, sharing his expertise with numerous organizations and conferences around the world. His contributions to the field have been widely recognized, earning him accolades and awards from various institutions and industry groups.

In addition to his professional endeavors, Childs has been actively involved in community service and philanthropy, supporting initiatives that aim to improve educational and economic opportunities for underrepresented groups. His commitment to social justice and equality has made him a respected figure not only in the business community but also in broader societal discussions on diversity and inclusion.

Ted Childs' legacy in the realm of diversity advocacy continues to influence modern corporate practices, as companies increasingly recognize the value of a diverse and inclusive workforce. His work has laid the groundwork for ongoing efforts to create equitable environments where all individuals can thrive, regardless of their background or identity.
wiki_bio_text: Ted Childs commenced training as a programme director with ABC Television in 1962. He went on to produce and direct a wide variety of factual programmes and documentary films, including episodes of This Week, then the ITV current affairs flagship, and also contributed to the acclaimed World at War series. He was one of the founding fathers of Euston Films, the film production company established by Thames Television in the early 1970s. Whilst there, he produced The Sweeney, Special Branch and Quatermass series, together with a number of theatrical and television films, as well as writing and/or directing films and series episodes for both ITV and the BBC. In 1984, he was appointed Controller of Drama at Central Television and, subsequently, Managing Director of Central Films. In this dual role, he acted as executive producer on an extensive range of films and series for ITV. These included Inspector Morse, Soldier Soldier, Peak Practice, Sharpe, Brother Cadfael, Chancer, Gone to the Dogs, Kavanagh QC and Thieftakers. Following the acquisition of Central Television by Carlton Communications, he opted to assume a freelance role. He continued to write and develop new television drama and films as an executive producer. As such, he was responsible for the Heat of the Sun series, the Morse film The Wench is Dead, the television films: Into the Blue, Goodnight Mr. Tom and The Waiting Time, together with a Kavanagh QC film special, the Monsignor Renard series and The Remorseful Day, the final episode in the Morse canon. In 2004/5 he was responsible for developing The Brief, a legal series. He acted as executive producer on two series of The Brief. He also acted as executive producer on Lewis, a television format derived from the Morse series. In 1991, the Production Guild honoured him with its annual Award of Merit. He was elected a Fellow of the Royal Television Society (RTS) in 1992. He was Chairman of the British Academy of Film and Television Arts (BAFTA) in 1994 and 1995. He received the RTS Award for Outstanding Creative Contribution to British Television in 1995. In the same year he was awarded the RTS Baird Medal for Outstanding Contribution to British Regional Television. In the 1997 New Year's Honours List, he was made an OBE for services to broadcast television. Also, in 1997, he was elected an Honorary Fellow of the Moving Image Society (formerly the British Kinematograph and Television Society). In May 1998, he received the BAFTA Award for Outstanding Creative Contribution to Television. In 2000, he received the Broadcasting Press Guild's Harvey Lee Award for Outstanding Contribution to Broadcasting. In July, 2015, the University of Nottingham awarded him the Honorary Degree of Doctor of Letters.

text_with_error:
Edward Synge (1659–1741) was an influential Irish Anglican clergyman who served as the Archbishop of Tuam from 1716 until his death in 1741. A prominent figure in the Church of Ireland during the early 18th century, Synge was known for his theological writings and efforts to bridge doctrinal divides within Protestantism. Born into a notable ecclesiastical family, he was the son of Edward Synge, Bishop of Cork, Cloyne, and Ross, and the brother of George Synge, who also held several significant positions within the church.

Educated at Trinity College Dublin, Synge demonstrated early academic promise, earning a Bachelor of Arts degree and later a Doctor of Divinity. His ascent within the ecclesiastical ranks was marked by a series of appointments, reflecting both his intellectual acumen and his commitment to the Anglican faith. Prior to his appointment as Archbishop of Tuam, he served as the Bishop of Raphoe from 1714 to 1716, where he gained a reputation for his pastoral care and administrative skill.

As Archbishop, Synge was actively involved in the religious and political life of Ireland. He played a key role in addressing the challenges faced by the Church of Ireland during a period marked by religious tension and sectarian conflict. Notably, he advocated for a more inclusive approach to Protestantism, promoting dialogue and understanding between different Protestant denominations. His theological writings, which often emphasized reason and moderation, contributed significantly to the religious discourse of his time.

Synge's tenure as Archbishop of Tuam occurred during a transformative period in Irish history, where issues such as tithes, land ownership, and the rights of Catholics were hotly debated. He was known for his pragmatic approach, often seeking to balance the interests of the church with those of the broader society. Despite the challenges of his era, Synge remained a steadfast advocate for the Church of Ireland's role in Irish spiritual and civic life.

Edward Synge passed away in 1741, leaving behind a legacy of religious scholarship and ecclesiastical leadership. His contributions to the Church of Ireland and his efforts to promote unity and understanding among Protestants continue to be recognized as significant aspects of his enduring influence.
wiki_bio_text: Edward Synge (1659–1741) was an Anglican clergyman who served in the Church of Ireland as Chancellor of St Patrick's Cathedral, Dublin (1705–1714), Bishop of Raphoe (1714–1716), and Archbishop of Tuam (1716–1741). Born on 6 April 1659 at Inishannon in County Cork, he was the second son of Edward Synge, Bishop of Cork, Cloyne and Ross. He was educated at Christ Church, Oxford and Trinity College, Dublin. He was nominated the Bishop of Raphoe on 7 October and consecrated on 7 November 1714. He was translated to the Archbishopric of Tuam by letters patent on 8 June 1716. A renowned preacher, his works were frequently published and included an exhortation to frequent communion translated into Welsh. Amongst other achievements, he established a dynasty of prominent ecclesiastics and literary figures closely integrated into the Protestant squirearchy in the west of Ireland. He died in office on 23 July 1741, aged 82. His sons were Edward Synge (Bishop of Elphin) and Nicholas Synge (Bishop of Killaloe).
